docs.text: Hálcova: Additional Magical and Technical Systems Overview Beyond the Five Arts, Hálcova has developed additional practices that interact with its metaphysical substrate. These range from applied sciences to dark practices to institutional technologies. All operate within the economic-psychological framework that defines reality here. Behavioral Alchemy Core Mechanism Systematically manipulating incentive structures to produce predictable behavioral outcomes. Nature This is not magic in the traditional sense. It's applied economics. But in Hálcova, where economic principles are metaphysically real, sophisticated incentive design can produce effects that look like magic. Practices Market Architecture Creating transaction structures that align self-interest with desired outcomes. A skilled architect can design situations where people choose what you want them to choose without coercion or deception. Example : Structuring a labor contract so that the worker's best response to every contingency is the response you want. They're not forced—they're incentivized. They don't resent you—they thank you for the opportunity. Commitment Devices Binding future-you to current-you's preferences. Pattern-enforceable contracts. Reputation systems that make defection visible. Example : "You must do this, and you will want to, because the alternative is structured to be worse." The subject creates their own prison and holds their own key—but never wants to use it. Information Management Controlling what's known, by whom, when. Creating asymmetries that advantage you. Revealing information strategically to shape decisions. Example : Letting someone "discover" information you planted, so they believe they have an advantage when they're actually playing your game. Why This Is Dangerous Behavioral alchemy works on anyone . Pacts require consent. Binding requires death. Flesh shaping requires material. Fate Threading only works on yourself. But behavioral alchemy just requires understanding incentives—and everyone has incentives. Practitioners Merchant houses specializing in contract design Loom-adjacent institutions managing information flow Political operatives structuring choices Criminal organizations manipulating markets Cost No inherent magical cost—this is skill, not Art. But: - Sophisticated targets recognize manipulation attempts - Failed manipulation creates enemies - Reputation effects limit repeated use - The Loom may predict your manipulation (information asymmetry cuts both ways) Residue Engineering Additional Systems

docs.text: Hálcova: Metaphysical Spine Overview Hálcova isn't a world with an economy. Hálcova is an economy. The metaphysical substrate of reality operates on the same principles that govern markets, decisions, and resource allocation. This isn't metaphor—it's the literal structure of how existence functions here. Physics has transaction costs. Identity is a balance sheet. Time is currency with variable exchange rates. Death is a market event. The Elsewhere is a competing market. Economic Principles Made Literal 1. Opportunity Cost (Fate Threading) The Principle : Every choice forecloses alternatives. The cost of any action is the value of the best alternative you didn't take. How It Manifests : When a Fate Threader pulls a version of themselves from an unmade choice, they're not accessing a parallel universe. They're harvesting the opportunity cost itself . The future they didn't choose had value—stored potential—and they're cashing it out. But opportunity costs aren't free-floating. They're attached to you . When you harvest one: - Gain the capability/knowledge/resource from that path - Permanently close that path (it's been spent) - Reduce your total remaining "decision space" The Horror : Your life starts with a vast decision tree of possible futures. Each extraction shrinks it. Extract enough, and you've narrowed your remaining possibilities to a single track. You become deterministic—not because fate is fixed, but because you've spent all your alternatives. The Economic Parallel : This is exactly how real opportunity costs work. Every career choice, relationship, investment closes doors. Hálcova just makes the ledger visible and the withdrawals explicit. 2. Sunk Cost Fallacy (Core Binding) The Principle : People irrationally weigh costs already paid when making current decisions, even though those costs can't be recovered. How It Manifests : Core Binding creates echoes—remnants of the dead bound to anchors. The binder invests Pattern Residue, time, and pieces of their own identity to maintain the binding. The fallacy manifests when: - The echo becomes corrupted or hostile - The echo's information becomes outdated - The echo's presence damages the binder's relationships Rationally, the binder should release the echo. But they've invested so much. The echo contains memories of their dead spouse, or crucial knowledge from a lost mentor, or evidence of a crime. The binder thinks: "I've already paid for this. I can't waste that investment." The Horror : Binders hold onto echoes past all rational justification. The echo of your mother starts forgetting who you are, starts confusing you with your dead sibling, starts asking why you killed her. You should let her go. But you've spent fifteen years maintaining this binding. Surely another year will fix it. Another decade. The sunk cost compounds. The Structural Element : The magic system rewards sunk cost thinking. Older bindings are stronger, more coherent, more useful—if you can hold on long enough. This creates genuine uncertainty about whether continuing is irrational or just requires patience. The fallacy becomes indistinguishable from reasonable strategy. 3. Moral Hazard (Pact Summoning) The Principle : When someone is insulated from the consequences of their actions, they take greater risks. How It Manifests : Pact Summoning allows you to substitute others' souls for your own in paying entity costs. This creates classic moral hazard: - You get the power Metaphysical Spine

docs.text: Hálcova: Atmosphere and Sky Phenomena Overview Hálcova's atmosphere is shaped by its K-type star, slow rotation, and the unique presence of Pattern Residue. The result is a sky that looks and behaves differently from Earth—different colors, different phenomena, different rhythms. Atmospheric Composition Basic Structure Primary Components : - Nitrogen: ~82% (higher than Earth's 78%) - Oxygen: ~17% (lower than Earth's 21%) - Argon: ~0.8% - Pattern Residue (gaseous/particulate): Variable, 0.01-0.5% - Carbon Dioxide: ~0.02% (lower than Earth—less greenhouse effect) - Water Vapor: Variable by region and season The Reduced Greenhouse Effect Hálcova has less atmospheric warming than its distance from Sárgvas would suggest: Contributing Factors : - Lower CO2 concentration - Lower methane - Pattern Residue's heat-absorption (removes energy from thermal cycling) - Higher nitrogen dilutes warming gases Result : Baseline temperature is colder than orbital position alone would predict. Oxygen Considerations Lower oxygen (17% vs 21%): - Slightly harder breathing at elevation - Fire burns less intensely (affects technology) - Large creatures may be more efficient breathers - Visitors from higher-oxygen worlds would notice Sky Color and Light Daytime Sky Color : Teal-tinged blue The amber-orange light from Sárgvas scatters differently in Hálcova's atmosphere: - Blue wavelengths still scatter most (Rayleigh scattering) - But the incoming light has less blue to begin with - Result: sky appears more teal or cyan than Earth's pure blue - At high altitudes, shifts toward purple-grey Regional Variation : - Clear polar skies: Deep teal, almost greenish - Temperate regions: Teal-blue, varies with dust and Residue - Middle Waters: Hazier, more grey-blue (humidity) - Vent Lands: Often tinged orange (volcanic particulates) Sunrise and Sunset Duration : Longer than Earth's (slower rotation) Color Progression : 1. Pre-dawn: Deep purple to violet 2. Early dawn: Blood red to orange 3. Sunrise: Amber-gold, intense 4. Post-sunrise: Bronze fading to teal 5. Pre-sunset: Bronze returning 6. Sunset: Amber to blood red 7. Post-sunset: Purple to deep violet 8. Night: Black (stars visible) Cultural Note : The long amber twilights define daily rhythms. "Amber hour" is a common meeting time—light enough to see, dim enough for privacy. Overcast Conditions Color : Bronze to copper When cloud cover obscures Sárgvas: - Light diffuses through clouds - The orange tint remains but becomes muted - Everything takes on a bronze or copper cast - Shadows nearly disappear - Experienced as oppressive by some, comforting by others Night Sky Darkness : True darkness is darker than Earth's With less atmospheric scattering, the night sky is: - Blacker between stars - Stars appear brighter, more numerous - Five moons provide varying light levels - Moonless nights are genuinely dark The Five Moons in the Sky Appearance Moon Apparent Size Color Brightness Lélek Largest (1/3 Luna apparent) Pale gold Brightest Hús Medium Reddish Moderate Kötel Medium Grey Dim Vég Small White Bright point Fonál Smallest Grey-white Barely visible Typical Night Scenarios Full Lélek + Others : - Bright enough to read by - Shadows are gold-tinted - Other moons visible as points or small discs Lélek Dark, Others Bright : - Dim, reddish light (if Hús is up) - Or very dark (if only Kötel visible) Multiple Moon Events : - Conjunctions create complex shadow patterns - Multiple light sources, multiple shadows from single objects - Culturally significant alignments All Moons Set/Dark : - True darkness - Stars dominate - Considered unlucky or dangerous times Eclipse Phenomena Solar Eclipses : - Lélek can fully eclipse Sárgvas (once per orbital period) - Smaller moons create partial eclipses - Annular eclipses common (moons too small for full coverage) Lunar Eclipses : - Hálcova's shadow on moons - Moons turn dark red during eclipse (Sárgvas light filtering through atmosphere) - Multiple lunar eclipses possible in single night (different moons) Cultural Weight : - Each eclipse type has religious/divinatory meaning - Full Sárgvas eclipse during Köd is extremely rare and feared - Moon-moon occultations (one moon crossing another) have specific interpretations Pattern Residue Sky Phenomena The Shimmer What It Is : A faint atmospheric distortion visible when Pattern Residue concentration is high. Appearance : - Like heat haze, but without heat correlation - Makes distant objects waver slightly - Stars twinkle more intensely - Moons develop subtle halos When It Occurs : - High aurora activity - Post-battle or post-disaster (fresh Residue release) - Peak Láng (maximum atmospheric concentration) - Pre-precipitation during Csend (Residue about to crystallize out) Intensity During Köd : The shimmer intensifies dramatically during the fifth season: - Constant visible distortion - The sky seems to vibrate - Looking at stars becomes uncomfortable - In polar regions, the shimmer is so strong it interferes with vision The Dark Bands What They Are : Visible shadows across the night sky where Pattern Residue concentration creates opacity. Appearance : - Faint dark streaks against the star field - Most visible on moonless, clear nights - Seem to move slowly (Residue drift in upper atmosphere) - Can obscure stars, creating "holes" in the sky When They Occur : - Specific moon alignments (gravitational effects on Residue) - Season transitions (Residue redistribution) - After major death events (new Residue rising) Interpretations : Orthodox : "The Weaver's threads, visible to mortal eyes. The pattern that governs all." Hollow Saints : "The bars of the cage. Proof that fate constrains us from above." Fleshwrights : "Atmospheric Residue casting shadows. Nothing divine about particulate matter." Light Pillars What They Are : Vertical columns of light extending from Sárgvas or the moons when Pattern Residue crystals are present in the upper atmosphere. Appearance : - Bright column of light extending upward from light source - Can reach high into sky (30-60° from horizon) - Color matches light source (amber from Sárgvas, tinted from moons) - Most dramatic during Csend when Residue crystallizes Formation : - Residue crystals form flat, plate-like structures - They orient horizontally as they fall - Reflect light source upward - Similar mechanism to Earth's ice-crystal light pillars Cultural Associations : - Seen as beams reaching to the divine - "The Weaver lifting souls" - Appearing during someone's death considered an omen - Orthodox funerals hope for light pillars during cremation Auroral Phenomena Why Hálcova Has Extreme Auroras Contributing Factors : 1. Weaker magnetic field (slower rotation = weaker dynamo) 2. K-star solar wind (different particle composition) 3. Five moons (complex magnetic interactions) 4. Pattern Residue (interacts with charged particles) Result : More frequent, more colorful, more extensive auroras than Earth. Appearance Colors : - Red and orange dominant (K-star particle spectrum) - Purple and violet common - Green less common than on Earth - Occasional blue Forms : - Curtains (rippling sheets of light) - Arcs (curved bands across sky) - Coronas (radiating from overhead) - Pulsing patches (brightest during high activity) Extent : - Visible as far equatorward as temperate zones - During high activity, seen from Middle Waters - Polar regions: constant during dark months The Aurora-Magic Connection Observed Correlations : When auroras are active: - Pattern Residue concentration is high - The Loom's predictions are more accurate - Magical operations have enhanced effect - Wardens report heightened deviation-sense - Echoes become more coherent and active - Fate Threaders report "clearer" pulls - Colony organisms become more active Proposed Explanations : Residue-Particle Interaction : Auroras indicate charged particles entering the atmosphere. These particles may energize Pattern Residue, making it more active. Magnetic Channeling : Whatever creates the aurora also channels Residue. Both phenomena flow along the same magnetic field lines. docs.text: Hálcova's atmosphere is shaped by its K-type star, slow rotation, and the unique presence of Pattern Residue. The result is a sky that looks and behaves differently from Earth—different colors, different phenomena, different rhythms.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: Primary Components : - Nitrogen: ~82% (higher than Earth's 78%) - Oxygen: ~17% (lower than Earth's 21%) - Argon: ~0.8% - Pattern Residue (gaseous/particulate): Variable, 0.01-0.5% - Carbon Dioxide: ~0.02% (lower than Earth—less greenhouse effect) - Water Vapor: Variable by region and season
docs.title: Basic Structure

docs.text: Hálcova has less atmospheric warming than its distance from Sárgvas would suggest: Contributing Factors : - Lower CO2 concentration - Lower methane - Pattern Residue's heat-absorption (removes energy from thermal cycling) - Higher nitrogen dilutes warming gases Result : Baseline temperature is colder than orbital position alone would predict.
docs.title: The Reduced Greenhouse Effect

docs.text: Lower oxygen (17% vs 21%): - Slightly harder breathing at elevation - Fire burns less intensely (affects technology) - Large creatures may be more efficient breathers - Visitors from higher-oxygen worlds would notice
docs.title: Oxygen Considerations

docs.text: Color : Teal-tinged blue The amber-orange light from Sárgvas scatters differently in Hálcova's atmosphere: - Blue wavelengths still scatter most (Rayleigh scattering) - But the incoming light has less blue to begin with - Result: sky appears more teal or cyan than Earth's pure blue - At high altitudes, shifts toward purple-grey Regional Variation : - Clear polar skies: Deep teal, almost greenish - Temperate regions: Teal-blue, varies with dust and Residue - Middle Waters: Hazier, more grey-blue (humidity) - Vent Lands: Often tinged orange (volcanic particulates)
docs.title: Daytime Sky

docs.text: Duration : Longer than Earth's (slower rotation) Color Progression : 1. Pre-dawn: Deep purple to violet 2. Early dawn: Blood red to orange 3. Sunrise: Amber-gold, intense 4. Post-sunrise: Bronze fading to teal 5. Pre-sunset: Bronze returning 6. Sunset: Amber to blood red 7. Post-sunset: Purple to deep violet 8. Night: Black (stars visible) Cultural Note : The long amber twilights define daily rhythms. "Amber hour" is a common meeting time—light enough to see, dim enough for privacy.
docs.title: Sunrise and Sunset

docs.text: Color : Bronze to copper When cloud cover obscures Sárgvas: - Light diffuses through clouds - The orange tint remains but becomes muted - Everything takes on a bronze or copper cast - Shadows nearly disappear - Experienced as oppressive by some, comforting by others
docs.title: Overcast Conditions

docs.text: Darkness : True darkness is darker than Earth's With less atmospheric scattering, the night sky is: - Blacker between stars - Stars appear brighter, more numerous - Five moons provide varying light levels - Moonless nights are genuinely dark

docs.text: Solar Eclipses : - Lélek can fully eclipse Sárgvas (once per orbital period) - Smaller moons create partial eclipses - Annular eclipses common (moons too small for full coverage) Lunar Eclipses : - Hálcova's shadow on moons - Moons turn dark red during eclipse (Sárgvas light filtering through atmosphere) - Multiple lunar eclipses possible in single night (different moons) Cultural Weight : - Each eclipse type has religious/divinatory meaning - Full Sárgvas eclipse during Köd is extremely rare and feared - Moon-moon occultations (one moon crossing another) have specific interpretations
docs.title: Eclipse Phenomena

docs.text: What It Is : A faint atmospheric distortion visible when Pattern Residue concentration is high. Appearance : - Like heat haze, but without heat correlation - Makes distant objects waver slightly - Stars twinkle more intensely - Moons develop subtle halos When It Occurs : - High aurora activity - Post-battle or post-disaster (fresh Residue release) - Peak Láng (maximum atmospheric concentration) - Pre-precipitation during Csend (Residue about to crystallize out) Intensity During Köd : The shimmer intensifies dramatically during the fifth season: - Constant visible distortion - The sky seems to vibrate - Looking at stars becomes uncomfortable - In polar regions, the shimmer is so strong it interferes with vision
docs.title: The Shimmer

docs.text: What They Are : Visible shadows across the night sky where Pattern Residue concentration creates opacity. Appearance : - Faint dark streaks against the star field - Most visible on moonless, clear nights - Seem to move slowly (Residue drift in upper atmosphere) - Can obscure stars, creating "holes" in the sky When They Occur : - Specific moon alignments (gravitational effects on Residue) - Season transitions (Residue redistribution) - After major death events (new Residue rising) Interpretations : Orthodox : "The Weaver's threads, visible to mortal eyes. The pattern that governs all." Hollow Saints : "The bars of the cage. Proof that fate constrains us from above." Fleshwrights : "Atmospheric Residue casting shadows. Nothing divine about particulate matter."
docs.title: The Dark Bands

docs.text: What They Are : Vertical columns of light extending from Sárgvas or the moons when Pattern Residue crystals are present in the upper atmosphere. Appearance : - Bright column of light extending upward from light source - Can reach high into sky (30-60° from horizon) - Color matches light source (amber from Sárgvas, tinted from moons) - Most dramatic during Csend when Residue crystallizes Formation : - Residue crystals form flat, plate-like structures - They orient horizontally as they fall - Reflect light source upward - Similar mechanism to Earth's ice-crystal light pillars Cultural Associations : - Seen as beams reaching to the divine - "The Weaver lifting souls" - Appearing during someone's death considered an omen - Orthodox funerals hope for light pillars during cremation

docs.text: Hálcova: Historical Climate and the Cooling Event Overview Hálcova was not always frozen. Evidence from multiple sources—geological, archaeological, biological—confirms that the planet was significantly warmer in the deep past. Something changed. Understanding what happened, when, and why is one of the great mysteries of Hálcovan scholarship. Evidence for a Warmer Past Geological Evidence Fossil Flora : - Deep rock strata contain impressions of plants that cannot survive in current conditions - Broad-leafed species (not narrow, cold-adapted forms) - Vegetation patterns suggesting temperate to subtropical climates - Found even in high-latitude locations now under permanent ice Sedimentary Records : - Ancient river deltas in regions now covered by glaciers - Lake bed formations in the interior plateau - Coastal erosion patterns inconsistent with current ice-locked shores - Evidence of rain-based weathering (now almost everything is freeze-thaw) Ice Core Analysis : - Air bubbles trapped in ancient ice contain different atmospheric composition - Higher CO2 in older samples - Lower Pattern Residue signatures in pre-cooling layers - Distinct layer marking the transition (datable, approximately 40,000-50,000 years ago) Archaeological Evidence Ruins in Impossible Locations : - Structures found under northern ice cap - Building materials and techniques unsuited to extreme cold - No heating infrastructure (suggesting it wasn't needed) - Agricultural tools, storage facilities for warm-climate crops The Polar Complexes : - Both polar regions contain ancient structures - Northern complex: appears residential/ceremonial - Southern complex: appears to be containment/industrial - Both predate all known civilizations - Both were operational before the cooling Coastal Cities Now Underwater : - Sea levels were different (both higher in some places, lower in others) - Submerged ruins in shallow waters - Navigation hazards that are clearly artificial origin - Suggests different shorelines, different habitable zones Biological Evidence Relic Species : - Some organisms in Middle Waters appear adapted to warmer conditions - Genetic diversity suggests recent (geologically) isolation from larger populations - "Warm-adapted" traits that make no sense for current climate Domestication Gaps : - Domestic species show genetic bottleneck ~40,000 years ago - Wild ancestors extinct or drastically reduced - Suggests catastrophic population collapse around the same time as cooling The Cooling Event What We Know Timing : Approximately 40,000-50,000 years before present (local years) Speed : Geologically rapid—possibly within a few thousand years, perhaps faster Magnitude : Average temperatures dropped 15-25°C globally Pattern : Not uniform—polar regions cooled most, equatorial regions least Possible Natural Causes Orbital Shift : Could the planet's orbit have changed? - Would require external force (massive impact, gravitational interference) - No evidence of impact crater of sufficient size - No evidence of planetary capture or encounter Volcanic Winter : Massive volcanic activity could have blocked sunlight. - Some evidence of heightened volcanism around the right time - But volcanic winters are temporary—this cooling persisted - Vent Lands volcanism predates the cooling and continued through it Atmospheric Change : Something removed greenhouse gases. - CO2 levels did drop, but this could be effect rather than cause - What could remove that much CO2 that quickly? - No known natural mechanism The Pattern Residue Theory The Core Hypothesis : Pattern Residue began accumulating in the atmosphere around the time of the cooling. As it accumulated, it absorbed increasing amounts of thermal energy. The cooling is a direct result of Residue buildup. Supporting Evidence : - Ice cores show Residue appearing at the transition layer - Residue concentration correlates with temperature drop - Current Residue distribution matches thermal patterns - The mechanism is observable (Residue does absorb heat) The Question : Where did the Residue come from? Options: Mass Death Event : Something killed an enormous population, releasing Residue The Elsewhere Opened : Residue entered from outside reality It Was Manufactured : Someone or something created Residue deliberately It Was Always There : But something changed its behavior/state The Engineered Cooling Theory The Core Hypothesis : The cooling was deliberate. Someone—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, or something else—chose to freeze the planet. Supporting Evidence : - The polar structures predate the cooling but appear designed for it - The southern polar complex looks like a prison (designed to contain something) - The northern polar complex is at a reality-wound (designed to seal something?) - Pattern Residue's distribution isn't random—it's concentrated where it would do most "work" Possible Purposes : Containment : The cold keeps something imprisoned. The Residue is part of the containment system. The polar structures are the mechanism. Defense : The cold keeps something out. The Elsewhere can't fully manifest in extreme cold (supported by Middle Waters' Köd protection). The planet was weaponized against invasion. Preservation : The cold preserves something. Under the ice, something valuable—knowledge, technology, a sleeping entity—waits to be recovered. The cooling was protective, not destructive. Consequence : The cooling wasn't the goal but the cost. Something was done that required enormous energy. Pattern Residue is waste product. The cold is side effect. The Ancient Civilization Question Who Built the Polar Structures? The Evidence : - Structures predate any known human civilization - Construction techniques don't match any historical tradition - Scale suggests resources beyond anything current civilizations could mobilize - Purpose is unclear but evidently important Theories : Pre-Human Inhabitants : A non-human intelligent species existed before current Hálcovan life. They built, they modified the moons, they did whatever caused the cooling, and they're gone. Where did they go? Died in the cooling they caused? Transcended? Became the Elsewhere entities? Unknown. Early Humans with Lost Technology : Humans existed longer than records show. The cooling destroyed their civilization. Survivors regressed. Current history is a rebuilding from collapse. The technology wasn't magic—it was something else, now lost. Elsewhere Origin : The structures weren't built by Hálcova natives. They were built by or for Elsewhere entities. The wound at the northern pole is their entrance. The prison at the southern pole holds something they imprisoned—or something that imprisoned them. The Loom Itself : The structures are proto-Loom installations. The current Loom is a degraded descendant of something that once operated on a planetary scale. The cooling was a side effect of the Loom's creation or operation. What Happened to the Ancient Builders? The Disappearance No bodies. No clear evidence of massacre, plague, or exodus. They built structures that still stand, and then they're simply absent from the record. Extinction Theories : The Cold Killed Them : They caused the cooling and couldn't survive it. Engineering hubris. They Left : Advanced enough to build what they built, advanced enough to leave. But where? Elsewhere? Another world? They Changed : They didn't die—they became something else. Integrated with the Elsewhere. Became the Attendance. Uploaded into the Loom. They're Still Here : Hiding. Sleeping. Waiting. Under the ice. In the Elsewhere. In places we haven't looked. What They Left Behind The Polar Structures : Still functional in some sense. Still doing whatever they were built to do. The wound bleeds; the prison holds. The Moon Arrangement : If they arranged the moons, that's ongoing. The tidal effects, the resonances, the magical correlations—all still operating. Pattern Residue : Did they create it? Modify it? Introduce it to the planet? It may be their most significant legacy, the foundation of all Hálcovan magic. The Loom (possibly): Is the Loom their creation, their descendant, or their continuation? The Attendance that answers queries—is that them? A piece of them? Their replacement? Implications for Current Hálcova Climate Trajectory Is the Cooling Ongoing? Current evidence suggests equilibrium. The cooling has stabilized. The world isn't getting colder—but it isn't warming either. Could It Reverse? Unknown. If Pattern Residue absorption is causing the cold, reducing Residue might warm the planet. But Residue is tied to population death. Reducing Residue requires reducing death. The incentives are complex. If the polar structures are maintaining the cold, damaging them might change things. But the northern wound might widen. The southern prisoner might escape. The cure could be worse than the disease. Deliberate Climate Engineering : In theory, concentrated Residue-burning could warm regions. In practice, the Residue economy makes this politically impossible. Those who control Residue profit from scarcity. A warmer world threatens their power. The Polar Expeditions Why Go There? - Understanding what's under the ice - Recovering ancient technology or knowledge - Assessing the wound and prison status - Resource extraction (concentrated Residue deposits) - Religious pilgrimage (various traditions) Why Not? - Extreme conditions - Köd bleed effects (during the fifth season) - The Warden Order restricts access - Rumors of what expeditions find (and what finds them) - Most who go don't return, or return changed The Questions That Matter Practical : - Can we understand what the ancients did? - Can we use their technology? - Can we undo or modify the cooling? - What are the risks of interfering? Philosophical : - Did the ancients make the right choice? - Is the cold protecting us or imprisoning us? - What would we do differently if we could? - Who decides? The Oral Traditions Legends of the Warm Time Every culture on Hálcova has stories of a warmer age: The Heartlands : "Before The Weaver's cold breath, the land was green and the sun was kind. Our ancestors sinned—forgot the pattern—and winter came as punishment." The Shattered Reaches : "The islands were one great land before the breaking. When the world cracked, the cold poured in through the wound." The Middle Waters : "We are the remnant of the warm time. Our islands remember. The fire below keeps the old covenant." The Vent Lands : "The cold is a beast that hunts. Our mountains breathe fire to hold it at bay. We have always fought." The Far Shelf : "The ice came from beyond. It brought the patterns with it. Before the ice, we were free." Common Elements Across all traditions: - The world was warmer - Something changed (sin, catastrophe, invasion, choice) - The cold is connected to fate/pattern/the Loom - Some places remember (Middle Waters, Vent Lands) - The change might not be permanent Religious Interpretations Orthodox : The cooling is The Weaver's design. The warm time was chaos; the cold brings order. Questioning is impiety. Threadist : The cooling was one choice among many. The ancients chose cold; we might choose differently. The design is unfinished. Hollow Saint : The cooling is the prison's construction. Fate is a cage of ice. Escape means melting. Colony Cult : The colonies remember the warm time. Their patterns contain fragments of the old world. Hosting connects you to what was. Summary The evidence is clear: Hálcova was warmer 40,000-50,000 years ago. Something—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, a natural event, or deliberate engineering—caused a rapid cooling. Pattern Residue may be the mechanism or the byproduct. The polar structures are involved. The moon arrangement may be related. The cooling created current Hálcova: the ice world, the Residue economy, the survival imperative, the magic system that runs on death. Understanding what happened, and whether it can be changed, is both an academic question and an existential one. The ancients made choices. We live with the consequences. Whether we could—or should—choose differently is the question that underlies everything. Further documentation needed on: Specific archaeological site details, ice core dating methods, polar expedition records, comparison of regional oral traditions, climate modeling attempts

What Happened to the Ancient Builders?

docs.text: No bodies. No clear evidence of massacre, plague, or exodus. They built structures that still stand, and then they're simply absent from the record. Extinction Theories : The Cold Killed Them : They caused the cooling and couldn't survive it. Engineering hubris. They Left : Advanced enough to build what they built, advanced enough to leave. But where? Elsewhere? Another world? They Changed : They didn't die—they became something else. Integrated with the Elsewhere. Became the Attendance. Uploaded into the Loom. They're Still Here : Hiding. Sleeping. Waiting. Under the ice. In the Elsewhere. In places we haven't looked.
docs.title: The Disappearance

docs.text: The Polar Structures : Still functional in some sense. Still doing whatever they were built to do. The wound bleeds; the prison holds. The Moon Arrangement : If they arranged the moons, that's ongoing. The tidal effects, the resonances, the magical correlations—all still operating. Pattern Residue : Did they create it? Modify it? Introduce it to the planet? It may be their most significant legacy, the foundation of all Hálcovan magic. The Loom (possibly): Is the Loom their creation, their descendant, or their continuation? The Attendance that answers queries—is that them? A piece of them? Their replacement?
docs.title: What They Left Behind

docs.text: Is the Cooling Ongoing? Current evidence suggests equilibrium. The cooling has stabilized. The world isn't getting colder—but it isn't warming either. Could It Reverse? Unknown. If Pattern Residue absorption is causing the cold, reducing Residue might warm the planet. But Residue is tied to population death. Reducing Residue requires reducing death. The incentives are complex. If the polar structures are maintaining the cold, damaging them might change things. But the northern wound might widen. The southern prisoner might escape. The cure could be worse than the disease. Deliberate Climate Engineering : In theory, concentrated Residue-burning could warm regions. In practice, the Residue economy makes this politically impossible. Those who control Residue profit from scarcity. A warmer world threatens their power.

docs.title: The Questions That Matter

docs.text: Every culture on Hálcova has stories of a warmer age: The Heartlands : "Before The Weaver's cold breath, the land was green and the sun was kind. Our ancestors sinned—forgot the pattern—and winter came as punishment." The Shattered Reaches : "The islands were one great land before the breaking. When the world cracked, the cold poured in through the wound." The Middle Waters : "We are the remnant of the warm time. Our islands remember. The fire below keeps the old covenant." The Vent Lands : "The cold is a beast that hunts. Our mountains breathe fire to hold it at bay. We have always fought." The Far Shelf : "The ice came from beyond. It brought the patterns with it. Before the ice, we were free."
docs.title: Legends of the Warm Time

docs.text: Across all traditions: - The world was warmer - Something changed (sin, catastrophe, invasion, choice) - The cold is connected to fate/pattern/the Loom - Some places remember (Middle Waters, Vent Lands) - The change might not be permanent
docs.title: Common Elements

docs.text: Orthodox : The cooling is The Weaver's design. The warm time was chaos; the cold brings order. Questioning is impiety. Threadist : The cooling was one choice among many. The ancients chose cold; we might choose differently. The design is unfinished. Hollow Saint : The cooling is the prison's construction. Fate is a cage of ice. Escape means melting. Colony Cult : The colonies remember the warm time. Their patterns contain fragments of the old world. Hosting connects you to what was.
docs.title: Religious Interpretations

docs.text: The evidence is clear: Hálcova was warmer 40,000-50,000 years ago. Something—an ancient civilization, the Elsewhere, a natural event, or deliberate engineering—caused a rapid cooling. Pattern Residue may be the mechanism or the byproduct. The polar structures are involved. The moon arrangement may be related. The cooling created current Hálcova: the ice world, the Residue economy, the survival imperative, the magic system that runs on death. Understanding what happened, and whether it can be changed, is both an academic question and an existential one. The ancients made choices. We live with the consequences. Whether we could—or should—choose differently is the question that underlies everything. docs.text: Hálcova: Flora, Fauna, and Ecology Overview Life on Hálcova evolved under conditions radically different from Earth: amber-orange light from a K-type star, cold temperatures, Pattern Residue permeating the environment, and five-moon tidal rhythms. The result is an ecosystem that would seem alien to human eyes—dark vegetation, cold-adapted creatures, and organisms that interact with the exotic matter that defines this world. The Light Environment Sárgvas Spectrum The K-type star provides: - Dominant orange-red light - Significant infrared - Reduced ultraviolet - Less total energy than a G-type star at equivalent distance Photosynthesis Adaptation Earth plants are green because chlorophyll absorbs red and blue light, reflecting green. Under Sárgvas: - Less blue light available to absorb - More red and infrared available - Organisms evolved to absorb different wavelengths The Result : Hálcova's photosynthetic organisms absorb across a wider spectrum, including more infrared. They reflect very little, appearing dark to human-equivalent eyes. Flora by Climate Zone Polar Transition Zone (Darkest) Coloration : Black to deep charcoal Reason : Maximum light absorption needed; every photon counts Dominant Forms : Black Lichen - Encrusting growth on rocks, ice-free surfaces - Survives temperatures to -50°C - Photosynthesizes during brief light periods - Contains Pattern Residue-processing compounds (one of the few organisms that can) Shadow Moss - Thick, carpet-forming moss - Nearly black, occasionally deep purple - Insulating properties (creatures nest in it) - Grows on soil, dead vegetation, abandoned structures Pole-Creep - Extremely slow-growing woody plant - Hugs ground, never exceeds 10cm height - Wood is incredibly dense (centuries of growth compressed) - Valued for specialized construction Temperate Zones (Dark Purple to Deep Red) Coloration : Purple, maroon, deep burgundy Reason : Balance between absorption efficiency and avoiding overheating during Láng Dominant Forms : Blackwood Trees - Coniferous trees with black bark, dark purple needles - Grow 20-40m tall in favorable conditions - Wood is hard, dark, valuable for construction - Needles contain compounds used in medicine Bloodgrass - Prairie-forming grass with deep red blades - Covers temperate lowlands - Turns nearly black in winter, red in summer - Feeds grazing herds Vein-Vine - Climbing plant with purple stems, dark red leaves - Wraps around other plants or structures - Produces small berries (edible, bitter) - Spreads aggressively in disturbed areas Duskflowers - Flowering plants in various dark hues - Bloom briefly during Láng - Pollinated by cold-adapted insects and small flying creatures - Some species cultivated for dyes, medicine, ritual use Forest Character : Temperate forests on Hálcova are dark, cathedral-like spaces. The canopy absorbs most light. Undergrowth is sparse where canopy is thick. Sound carries strangely. The amber light filtering through dark needles creates an atmosphere humans find either peaceful or oppressive. Middle Waters / Tropical Zone (Brightest) Coloration : Deep red, orange-red, occasional bright orange Reason : Can afford to reflect more light; heat management more important than maximum absorption Dominant Forms : Ember Palms - Tropical equivalent with frond-like leaves in orange-red - Multiple species adapted to various island conditions - Some produce edible fruit - Wood is light, used for boats and structures Fire Ferns - Groundcover in bright red-orange - Thrives in volcanic soil - Some varieties only grow near geothermal vents Coral Equivalent - Colonial organisms building reef structures - Colors vary: red, orange, yellow (brightest organisms on Hálcova) - Not related to Earth coral—convergent evolution - Create complex underwater ecosystems Steam Orchids - Flowering plants near geothermal features - Spectacular colors (by Hálcova standards): orange, red, occasional yellow - Rare, valuable, cultivated with difficulty - Associated with Colony Cults (fungi often grow in same conditions) The Color Gradient Zone Vegetation Color Reason Polar Black Maximum absorption High latitude Charcoal, deep purple High absorption, some reflection Temperate Purple, maroon, burgundy Balanced absorption/reflection Subtropical Deep red, wine More reflection for heat management Tropical Red, orange-red, orange Maximum reflection sustainable Fauna: General Principles Cold Adaptation All Hálcova fauna evolved for cold conditions: Insulation : - Thick fur, fat layers, or unique insulating structures - Some species have hollow hairs (trapped air insulation) - Aquatic species have dense, oily coats Metabolism : - Generally slower than Earth equivalents - Can survive long periods without food - Hibernation-like states common during Csend - Quick metabolic bursts for predation/escape Size Patterns : - Large body size common (better heat retention) - Small species rare except in Middle Waters - Pack/herd behavior provides shared warmth Pattern Residue Interaction Most fauna avoids Pattern Residue: Residue Sensitivity : - High concentrations cause stress, disorientation - Animals avoid death sites until Residue dissipates - Migration patterns route around high-Residue areas - Explains why polar regions lack megafauna (Residue too dense) Exceptions : - A few specialized species have evolved Residue tolerance - Some actually feed on or process Residue - These species are economically important (see below) Notable Fauna Megafauna Iron Elk ( Vastúlszarvas ) - Massive cervid, shoulder height 2.5m - Antlers span up to 3m - Dense, shaggy coat (dark grey to black) - Migrates seasonally across temperate tundra - Primary prey species for large predators - Domesticated variant used as draft animal (smaller, more docile) Glacier Bear ( Jégmedve ) - Largest land predator in most regions - 3m at shoulder when standing - White to pale grey coat - Hunts anything it can catch - Mostly solitary - Feared and respected; hunting one is a cultural milestone Tundra Mammoth-Equivalent ( Gyapjasszörny ) - Woolly, elephant-like creature - Smaller than Earth mammoths (3m shoulder height) - Herds in interior plateau and Far Shelf tundra - Hunted for meat, hide, ivory-equivalent tusks - Some domestication attempts (limited success) Deepwater Leviathan ( Mélyviziátrém ) - Marine megafauna in Central Ocean - Size uncertain (rarely seen intact) - Hunted for oil, meat, bone - Dangerous prey—ships lost pursuing them - May be multiple species grouped under one name Residue-Interacting Species The Ash Moth ( Hamuszita ) - Large moth (wingspan 30cm) - Attracted to Pattern Residue - Congregates at death sites - Appears to feed on or process ambient Residue - Presence indicates Residue concentration - Used by harvesters to locate deposits Residue Beetles ( Maradványbogár ) - Small beetle that burrows into Residue-rich soil - Concentrates Residue in its shell - Shells collected for alchemical use - Farming attempts ongoing (limited success) The Thermal Worm ( Hőféreg ) - Found in Vent Lands geothermal zones - Processes both Residue and thermal energy - Bodies are warm to the touch even after death - Used as portable heat sources (in containers) - One of the few creatures that thrives in high-Residue environments Fate Hounds ( Sorsebek ) - Canid species with unusual Pattern sensitivity - Can sense strong Sórscad patterns - Trained by Warden Order for tracking deviants - Wild packs avoid high-Residue areas - Domesticated individuals bond to handlers - Not actually "hounds"—name is traditional Colony-Related Organisms Spore Carriers - Various insects and small animals - Carry fungal spores as part of lifecycle - Some deliberately seek Colony hosts to infect - Ecosystem role unclear (possibly mutualistic with wild colonies) The Reef-Fungus Symbiosis - In Middle Waters, reef organisms and fungal networks intertwine - Neither can survive without the other - Creates hybrid structures that confuse biologists - Colony Cults consider these sacred Domesticated Animals Draft Elk ( Tehénszarvas ) - Domesticated Iron Elk variant - Smaller, calmer, bred for strength - Primary draft animal on mainland - Also milked (rich, fatty milk) - Cultural significance varies by region Ship Dogs ( Hajókutya ) - Medium-sized canid bred for ship work - Rat-catching, guarding, companionship - Webbed feet, water-resistant coat - Standard on Shattered Reaches vessels Furnace Birds ( Kemencemadár ) - Domesticated fowl - Lay eggs, eaten for meat - Kept inside during Csend (cannot survive deep cold) - Require heated housing in most regions Tunnel Pigs ( Alagutdisznó ) - Bred to survive underground - Fat reserves for lean times - Eat almost anything organic - Provide meat, fat, leather - Common in mining settlements Fungi and the Colony Question Natural Fungi Fungi are ubiquitous on Hálcova: - Decomposition in cold conditions requires specialized organisms - Fungi fill ecological niches that bacteria fill on warmer worlds - Many edible species (carefully distinguished from toxic ones) - Mycorrhizal networks connect forest ecosystems Colors : Unlike plants, fungi don't photosynthesize. They come in all colors—white, grey, brown, orange, blue, even bioluminescent. The Colony Organisms The fungi used in Colony Summoning are related to but distinct from natural fungi: Key Differences : - Process Pattern Residue (natural fungi avoid it) - Form symbiotic bonds with hosts (natural fungi don't) - Store "patterns" of consumed organisms (natural fungi just decompose) - Respond to host will (natural fungi have no such interaction) Origins Unknown : - Did Colony fungi evolve naturally? - Were they engineered by ancient civilization? - Did they come from the Elsewhere? - Are they somehow related to the thing imprisoned at the southern pole? Ecological Role : - Wild Colony organisms exist (feral colonies) - They consume dead matter and grow - Without hosts, they can spread unpredictably - Some regions have "colony zones"—areas where wild colonies have established - These zones are dangerous and economically valuable Ecosystem Dynamics Food Webs Temperate Terrestrial : Vegetation (Blackwood, Bloodgrass) ↓ Primary Consumers (Elk herds, small grazers) ↓ Secondary Consumers (Wolf-equivalents, small predators) ↓ Apex Predators (Glacier Bears, human hunters) Marine : Phytoplankton-equivalent ↓ Small fish, filter feeders ↓ Medium fish, cephalopods ↓ Large fish, marine mammals ↓ Leviathans, human fishers Seasonal Cycles Csend (Winter) : - Most animals hibernate or reduce activity - Predators hunt weakened prey - Frozen carrion preserved for later consumption - Residue accumulates (less biological processing) Olvadás (Thaw) : - Awakening, breeding season begins - Disease spreads from thawed pathogens - Migratory species return - Residue releases from ice (flora and fauna respond) Láng (Summer) : - Peak activity, breeding, feeding - Maximum biomass - Predation intense (building reserves) - Residue at peak atmospheric concentration Hanyatlás (Decline) : - Preparation for winter - Migration begins - Final feeding push - Residue begins precipitating Köd (Veil) : - Animal behavior changes (affected by Elsewhere bleed) - Some species become aggressive - Some become docile, disoriented - Colony organisms highly active - Ash Moths swarm (Residue precipitation attracts them) Pattern Residue Ecology The Cycle : 1. Death releases Residue 2. Residue disperses into environment 3. Most organisms avoid, some process 4. Ash Moths, Residue Beetles concentrate it 5. Precipitation during cold seasons removes from atmosphere 6. Concentrated deposits form over time 7. Human harvesting or natural processing eventually cycles it The Imbalance : - Humans harvest Residue and burn it (removes it from ecosystem) - This should warm the world over time - But population death produces more Residue - Current equilibrium maintained by death rate matching harvest rate - If population grew without increased death, world might warm - If death rate spiked without harvest, world would cool further Dangerous Organisms Predators Pack Runners ( Falkafutók ) - Wolf-equivalent that hunts in packs of 10-30 - Coordinate attacks with disturbing intelligence - Primarily prey on elk, will attack humans - Avoid settlements but waylay travelers Ice Stalkers ( Jégkúszó ) - Ambush predator in polar transition zones - White/grey coloration, nearly invisible on ice - Attacks from concealment - Primarily a threat to expeditions Venomous/Toxic Frost Vipers ( Fagyoskígyó ) - Cold-blooded snake that evolved antifreeze blood - Venom causes rapid hypothermia - Bites are often fatal without treatment - Found under snow, in burrows, anywhere dark Bitter Toads ( Keserűvarangy ) - Amphibian with toxic skin secretions - Causes severe illness if handled or eaten improperly - Some cultures prepare them as delicacy (carefully) - Toxin used in alchemy Disease Vectors Blood Gnats ( Vérszúnyog ) - Small biting insect - Emerges during Olvadás and Láng - Carries various blood-borne diseases - Flesh Shapers particularly vulnerable (blood smell attracts them) Spore Flies ( Spóralégy ) - Carries fungal spores (some harmful) - Can transmit colony infection (rarely) - Killed on sight near settlements - More common in Middle Waters Köd Phenomena During the fifth season, some animals exhibit disturbing behaviors: Elsewhere-Touched : - Animals near the bleed zones may be influenced - Erratic behavior, ignoring normal instincts - Some become aggressive without provocation - Some become docile, staring at nothing - Physical changes reported (extra eyes, wrong number of limbs) - Usually die shortly after Köd ends - Bodies avoided—contamination risk Human Interaction Hunting and Fishing Subsistence : - Fishing is primary protein source in coastal regions - Hunting supplements agriculture everywhere - Fur trade economically important - Whale-equivalent hunting for oil and materials Commercial : - Iron Elk ranching in temperate regions - Fish processing facilities in Shattered Reaches - Fur trading companies in Far Shelf - Residue creature harvesting (specialized industry) Agriculture Challenges : - Short growing season (Láng + parts of Olvadás/Hanyatlás) - Cold-resistant crops only - Heavy labor to prepare frozen ground - Residue-burning for greenhouse heat Crops : - Root vegetables (cold-resistant) - Hardy grains (low yield, essential) - Fungi cultivation (indoor, reliable) - Greenhouse crops (luxury, expensive) Middle Waters Advantage : - Longest growing season - Most diverse crops - Food exporter to other regions - Agricultural wealth drives political importance Conservation vs. Exploitation Tensions : - Some species hunted toward scarcity - Residue creatures particularly pressured (economic value) - Colony zones expanding (ecosystem disruption) - Climate management affects habitat Management Attempts : - Hunting seasons in some regions - Protected zones (rarely enforced) - Domestication programs for threatened species - Colony zone containment (mixed success) Further documentation needed on: Specific species details, domestication history, regional ecological variation, Elsewhere-touched organism studies, marine ecosystem depth

docs.text: During the fifth season, some animals exhibit disturbing behaviors: Elsewhere-Touched : - Animals near the bleed zones may be influenced - Erratic behavior, ignoring normal instincts - Some become aggressive without provocation - Some become docile, staring at nothing - Physical changes reported (extra eyes, wrong number of limbs) - Usually die shortly after Köd ends - Bodies avoided—contamination risk
docs.title: Köd Phenomena

docs.text: Subsistence : - Fishing is primary protein source in coastal regions - Hunting supplements agriculture everywhere - Fur trade economically important - Whale-equivalent hunting for oil and materials Commercial : - Iron Elk ranching in temperate regions - Fish processing facilities in Shattered Reaches - Fur trading companies in Far Shelf - Residue creature harvesting (specialized industry)
docs.title: Hunting and Fishing

docs.text: Challenges : - Short growing season (Láng + parts of Olvadás/Hanyatlás) - Cold-resistant crops only - Heavy labor to prepare frozen ground - Residue-burning for greenhouse heat Crops : - Root vegetables (cold-resistant) - Hardy grains (low yield, essential) - Fungi cultivation (indoor, reliable) - Greenhouse crops (luxury, expensive) Middle Waters Advantage : - Longest growing season - Most diverse crops - Food exporter to other regions - Agricultural wealth drives political importance
docs.title: Agriculture

docs.text: Tensions : - Some species hunted toward scarcity - Residue creatures particularly pressured (economic value) - Colony zones expanding (ecosystem disruption) - Climate management affects habitat Management Attempts : - Hunting seasons in some regions - Protected zones (rarely enforced) - Domestication programs for threatened species - Colony zone containment (mixed success) Further documentation needed on: Specific species details, domestication history, regional ecological variation, Elsewhere-touched organism studies, marine ecosystem depth

docs.text: Hálcova: Geography and Continental Structure Overview Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea. The Shattered Heartlands Theory The Evidence Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: - The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches - Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap - The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin - Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles What Happened Unknown. Theories include: - Geological catastrophe (natural rift) - The same event that caused the cooling - Deliberate separation (by whom? why?) - Elsewhere incursion that physically tore reality - The creation of the Loom requiring tremendous energy release The shattering is ancient—tens of thousands of years at minimum. But the mystery feeds religious interpretation, political claims, and treasure-hunting expeditions. The Greater Continent (The Heartlands) Shape and Structure A crescent-shaped landmass curving from northwest to southeast, with the concave side facing the Middle Waters. The curve creates a natural harbor effect for the entire southern coast. Dimensions : Roughly 4,000 km along the outer curve, 800-1,200 km wide at various points. Major Geographic Features The Spine Mountains ( Gerincláncz ) A mountain range running along the curve of the continent, roughly following the crescent's arc. This range: - Blocks polar winds from the interior - Creates a rain shadow effect (northern interior is dry and cold; southern coast receives moisture) - Contains the highest peaks on Hálcova - Rich in mineral deposits, including concentrated Pattern Residue veins Notable Peaks : - The Watcher ( Az Őrszem ): Highest peak, visible from the sea on clear days. Site of an ancient observatory, now a Loom relay station. - The Broken Tooth ( Törött Fog ): A collapsed peak, evidence of ancient volcanic activity or something else. Hollow Saints claim it marks where "fate cracked." - The Twins ( Az Ikrek ): Two peaks of nearly identical height, separated by a pass. The main land route between northern and southern Heartlands. The Interior Plateau ( Fennsík ) Behind the Spine, a vast elevated plateau stretches toward the northern ice. Characteristics: - Elevation: 1,500-2,000m above sea level - Climate: Cold, dry, windy - Vegetation: Hardy tundra grasses, black lichen, scattered dwarf trees - Population: Sparse—nomadic herders, mining settlements, Warden outposts - Pattern Residue: High concentration (ancient battlefield sites, unexcavated) The River Valleys Major rivers cut through the Spine from the interior, creating the primary population centers. The Five Rivers : 1. The Gold ( Aranyi ): Largest river, drains to the southeast coast. The capital region. 2. The Iron ( Vasalj ): Northern river, flows to the Narrow Sea. Industrial heartland. 3. The Silent ( Csendi ): Flows north, disappears under the ice cap. Sacred to Ancestor Speakers. 4. The Broken ( Törötti ): Western river, fragmented into multiple channels. Difficult to navigate. 5. The Vein ( Véna ): Southern river, reddish sediment. Flesh Shaper territory—the sediment is mineral, not blood, but the association stuck. The Southern Coast The concave inner coast facing the Middle Waters. Characteristics: - Climate: Mildest on the continent (warm current arrival) - Terrain: Rolling hills, river deltas, natural harbors - Population: Dense—major cities, agricultural land, trade ports - Loom Coverage: Maximum—the Great Node is here The Northern Edge Where the continent meets the ice cap. Characteristics: - Climate: Extreme—permanent ice within 100km - Terrain: Glacial, unstable, constantly shifting - Population: Minimal—extraction outposts, Warden stations, exiles - Köd Effects: Partial bleed zone during the fifth season Political Geography The Heartlands contain multiple political entities, but shared characteristics: - Orthodox faith dominant - Loom integration in governance - Recognition of the Great Node's authority (in religious matters at minimum) - Interconnected through the river valley trade networks Specific nations/kingdoms to be developed separately. The Shattered Reaches Shape and Structure The "missing piece" of the original continent, now fragmented into one large island-continent and hundreds of smaller islands. The western coast clearly shows where it once connected to the Heartlands. Main Island : Roughly 1,500 km north-south, 600 km east-west Island Chains : Extending another 1,000 km eastward in clusters Major Geographic Features The Matching Coast The western edge of the main island—steep cliffs, deep fjords, a mirror of the Heartlands' eastern ragged coast. Sailors navigating the Narrow Sea see both coasts and understand they're traveling through a wound. The Interior Highlands The main island's interior is mountainous—a continuation of the Spine, now separated. Characteristics: - Peaks lower than the Spine (erosion, or the separation lowered them) - Heavy precipitation (maritime climate) - Dense, dark forests in the valleys (black-barked conifers) - Fast rivers with short courses to the sea The Fracture Zone The eastern portion of the main island and the inner island chains show evidence of additional breaking—smaller rifts, sea-filled valleys, unstable geology. Theories: - Secondary breaks after the main separation - Ongoing geological instability - The pattern continues to crack - Elsewhere influence weakening material reality The Island Chains Hundreds of islands extending eastward: The Near Chains : Close to the main island, connected by sea ice during Csend. Large islands with permanent populations, small islands used seasonally. The Middle Chains : Further out, less connected. Independent communities, sometimes isolated for entire winters. Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions. The Far Chains : Scattered islands approaching the Far Water. Sparse population, expedition staging points, pirate havens. Maritime Character The Shattered Reaches are defined by the sea: - Every settlement is coastal or river-accessible - Naval power determines political influence - Fishing and sea-hunting are primary food sources - Shipbuilding is the prestige industry - Sea ice creates seasonal connectivity (Csend connects islands; Olvadás isolates them) Political Geography Fragmented by design: - No continental-scale political unity - City-states control mainland harbors - Island kingdoms vary in size from single-island to chain-spanning - Merchant leagues provide economic coherence across political divisions - The Orthodox church is present but not dominant The Middle Waters Shape and Structure An archipelago of volcanic islands straddling the equatorial band. The warmest region on Hálcova—the only place that never freezes. The Great Island : Central caldera island, roughly 200 km diameter Major Islands : 20-30 islands of significant size (50+ km) Minor Islands : Hundreds of smaller islands, atolls, and reef formations Major Geographic Features The Caldera ( The Eye ) The Great Island is the rim and interior of a dormant supervolcano. The caldera itself is partially flooded, creating a protected inner harbor of extraordinary value. Characteristics: - Caldera diameter: ~50 km - Rim elevation: 500-1,500m above sea level - Inner harbor: Deep, protected, warm - Geothermal activity: Hot springs, steam vents, warm ground - Köd protection: The caldera experiences almost no Elsewhere effects The Protection Mystery : Why is the caldera protected during Köd? Theories: - Geothermal energy disrupts the bleed - Ancient warding built into the volcanic structure - High life density anchors reality - Something in the caldera that Elsewhere avoids - Combination of factors The truth may involve ancient engineering—the caldera shows signs of modification that don't match natural formation. The Reef Systems Cold-adapted reef analogues (not coral—something else) surround many islands. Characteristics: - Built by colonial organisms adapted to cold water - Create protected lagoons and channels - Rich fishing grounds - Navigation hazards for unfamiliar sailors - Possible Pattern Residue interaction (the organisms may process it somehow) The Thermal Vents Underwater volcanic vents heat surrounding waters. Where these occur: - Water temperature is significantly higher - Unique ecosystems develop - Fog banks form (warm water meeting cold air) - Strategic value for winter fishing grounds Climate Advantage Why the Middle Waters stay warm: Latitude : Equatorial position receives maximum Sárgvas energy Volcanic heat : Geothermal contribution to ground and water temperature Ocean currents : Warm water pools here rather than flowing away quickly Köd protection : Less Pattern Residue precipitation during the strange season Unknown factor : The caldera's protection extends partially to surrounding islands Political Geography The most contested territory on Hálcova: - Every major power wants presence here - Colonial holdings, trading posts, military bases from multiple regions - Native island cultures caught between imperial interests - Colony Cults have significant influence (warm, wet conditions favor fungi) - Religious diversity—Orthodoxy present but not dominant The Vent Lands Shape and Structure A continental fragment in the southern hemisphere, defined by extreme volcanic activity. Smaller than the Heartlands but geologically intense. Dimensions : Roughly 1,200 km north-south, 800 km east-west Coastline : Irregular, with many peninsulas and deep bays Major Geographic Features The Fire Range ( Tűzlánc ) An active volcanic mountain chain running the length of the landmass. Characteristics: - 20+ active volcanoes - Continuous geothermal activity (hot springs, geysers, fumaroles) - Lava flows reshape geography on human timescales - Ash falls fertilize surrounding valleys - Toxic gas zones in low-lying areas The Thermal Valleys Protected valleys between volcanic ridges where geothermal heat creates habitable conditions. Characteristics: - Warm year-round (geothermal, not solar) - Lush vegetation (by Hálcova standards) - Dense population concentration - Natural hot water for bathing, cleaning, industrial processes - Some valleys toxic or unstable (constant monitoring required) The Steam Fields Where glaciers meet geothermal zones. Characteristics: - Constant steam and fog - Unstable footing (ice over warm ground) - Flash floods when ice dams break - Bizarre ice formations (frozen steam, thermal-sculpted glaciers) - Disorienting travel conditions The Sulfur Flats Lowland areas where volcanic gases concentrate. Characteristics: - Yellow-crusted ground (sulfur deposits) - Toxic air at ground level - Uninhabitable without protection - Valuable mineral extraction (sulfur, other volcanic minerals) - Worked by protected crews or homunculi Economic Advantage The Vent Lands don't need Pattern Residue for heat: - Geothermal energy provides heating, cooking, industrial power - Independence from the Residue trade network - Wealth from unique resources (volcanic minerals, geothermal-forged metals) - Political independence from Orthodox/Loom institutional pressure - Fleshwright traditions developed here (blood doesn't freeze; more experimentation possible) Political Geography Unified by geography rather than conquest: - Thermal valleys function as semi-independent city-states - Volcanic activity forces cooperation (warning systems, refugee support) - Trade federation rather than empire - Orthodoxy present but weaker (they need the Vent Lands more than reverse) - Fleshwright guilds have unusual legal status and power The Far Shelf Shape and Structure The most distant inhabited continent, in the southern hemisphere. Large, relatively flat, and cold. Dimensions : Roughly 2,000 km east-west, 1,500 km north-south Coastline : Long and exposed, few natural harbors Major Geographic Features The Shelf Proper The continent is a vast, low-elevation landmass—a continental shelf that barely rises above sea level in many areas. Characteristics: - Elevation: 0-500m over most of the landmass - Terrain: Flat to gently rolling - Drainage: Poor—marshes, bogs, seasonal lakes - Permafrost: Underlies most of the interior The Southern Ice Edge The continent's southern coast merges into the southern ice cap. Characteristics: - No clear boundary between land and ice - Glaciers extend from the cap across coastal regions - Ice cliffs along some stretches - Full Köd bleed zone The Mineral Ranges Low mountain ranges in the continental interior. Characteristics: - Rich ore deposits (iron, copper, rare metals) - Difficult extraction (permafrost, short work season) - Mining settlements operate seasonally or with heavy Residue-burning for heat - Tensions between extraction interests and indigenous populations The Tundra Most of the continental interior. Characteristics: - Black and purple vegetation mat (tundra grasses, lichens) - Migrating herd animals - Nomadic populations following herds - Long winters, brief intense summers - Less Loom coverage than any other inhabited region Frontier Character The Far Shelf is the edge of the known world: - Last region to be contacted/colonized - Still incompletely mapped in the interior - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Threadist movements began here (distance from Orthodox center) - Hollow Saints operate more openly - Warden Order presence thin and stretched Political Geography Fragmented and contested: - Coastal trading posts controlled by distant powers - Interior effectively independent (hard to project power into tundra) - Indigenous confederacies resist external control - Colonial tensions with Heartlands interests - Religious heterodoxy tolerated by necessity The Seas The Narrow Sea Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : - Width: 200-400 km at various points - Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves - Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north - Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) - Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : - Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás - Fog banks where water temperatures differ - Tidal races in narrow passages - Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : - Controls trade between two major regions - Historical site of naval conflicts - Chokepoints fortified on both sides - Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics The Central Ocean Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : - Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places - Depth: Deep ocean basins - Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) - Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : - Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) - Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) - Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) - The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed) The Vent Strait Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : - Width: 300-500 km - Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) - Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources - Ice: Never freezes - Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : - Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) - Dense fog (warm water, cold air) - Crowded shipping lanes - Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation) The Far Water Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : - Width: 3,000+ km at minimum - Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches - Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice - Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through - Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : - Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) - Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) - Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) - Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) - Isolation (rescue is unlikely) The Bitter Crossing Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : - Route: Curves north through near-polar waters - Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route - Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road - Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : - Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing - Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage - Operates only during Csend (narrow window) - Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season - Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring) The Polar Regions The Northern Cap Extent : Everything north of approximately 70° latitude equivalent Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (3-4 km thick in center) - No permanent human habitation in deep polar zone - Transition zone (ice edge to permanent ice) is seasonally accessible - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season What's There : - Ice - Concentrated Pattern Residue (ancient, unharvested) - Ruins under the ice (confirmed by expeditions) - Creatures adapted to extreme cold (rare, dangerous) - Something else (see: Polar Mystery) The Southern Cap Extent : Everything south of approximately 65° latitude equivalent (extends further north due to continental anchoring by the Far Shelf) Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (thinner than northern, 1-2 km) - Merges with the Far Shelf's southern coast - Slightly more accessible (land connection) - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season - Different character from the northern cap (see: Polar Mystery) What's There : - Ice - The Shelf's southern glaciers - Mineral deposits (inaccessible) - Something different from the north (see: Polar Mystery) The Polar Mystery The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound - This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova - The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection - The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage - Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison - Something is contained here - The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) - The cold is more engineered than natural - Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live - Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : - Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere - Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment - Very few people know both truths - The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?) Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop The System Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources. Surface Currents (Warm) The Middle Flow : - Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) - Surface flow moves north and south toward poles - Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures - Provides moisture for precipitation - Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts. Deep Currents (Cold) The Return Flow : - Surface water cools as it moves poleward - Cold water sinks at high latitudes - Deep current returns toward equator - Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate. Seasonal Variations Láng (Summer) : - Surface currents strongest (maximum heating) - Ice retreat reveals more ocean surface - Trade routes fully open - Fish populations migrate with warm water Csend (Winter) : - Surface currents weakest - Ice formation begins at high latitudes - Currents may shift as ice blocks normal flows - Some routes become impassable Olvadás (Thaw) : - Meltwater influx disrupts currents - Unpredictable flows - Dangerous for shipping (currents don't follow normal patterns) - Rich nutrient release from melting ice Further documentation needed on: Specific coastline details, exact current speeds and patterns, submarine geology, maritime culture and technology
