docs.text: Unified by geography rather than conquest: - Thermal valleys function as semi-independent city-states - Volcanic activity forces cooperation (warning systems, refugee support) - Trade federation rather than empire - Orthodoxy present but weaker (they need the Vent Lands more than reverse) - Fleshwright guilds have unusual legal status and power
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: The most distant inhabited continent, in the southern hemisphere. Large, relatively flat, and cold. Dimensions : Roughly 2,000 km east-west, 1,500 km north-south Coastline : Long and exposed, few natural harbors
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Shelf Proper The continent is a vast, low-elevation landmass—a continental shelf that barely rises above sea level in many areas. Characteristics: - Elevation: 0-500m over most of the landmass - Terrain: Flat to gently rolling - Drainage: Poor—marshes, bogs, seasonal lakes - Permafrost: Underlies most of the interior The Southern Ice Edge The continent's southern coast merges into the southern ice cap. Characteristics: - No clear boundary between land and ice - Glaciers extend from the cap across coastal regions - Ice cliffs along some stretches - Full Köd bleed zone The Mineral Ranges Low mountain ranges in the continental interior. Characteristics: - Rich ore deposits (iron, copper, rare metals) - Difficult extraction (permafrost, short work season) - Mining settlements operate seasonally or with heavy Residue-burning for heat - Tensions between extraction interests and indigenous populations The Tundra Most of the continental interior. Characteristics: - Black and purple vegetation mat (tundra grasses, lichens) - Migrating herd animals - Nomadic populations following herds - Long winters, brief intense summers - Less Loom coverage than any other inhabited region
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Far Shelf is the edge of the known world: - Last region to be contacted/colonized - Still incompletely mapped in the interior - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Threadist movements began here (distance from Orthodox center) - Hollow Saints operate more openly - Warden Order presence thin and stretched
docs.title: Frontier Character

docs.text: Fragmented and contested: - Coastal trading posts controlled by distant powers - Interior effectively independent (hard to project power into tundra) - Indigenous confederacies resist external control - Colonial tensions with Heartlands interests - Religious heterodoxy tolerated by necessity
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : - Width: 200-400 km at various points - Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves - Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north - Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) - Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : - Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás - Fog banks where water temperatures differ - Tidal races in narrow passages - Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : - Controls trade between two major regions - Historical site of naval conflicts - Chokepoints fortified on both sides - Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics
docs.title: The Narrow Sea

docs.text: Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : - Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places - Depth: Deep ocean basins - Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) - Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : - Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) - Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) - Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) - The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed)
docs.title: The Central Ocean

docs.text: Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : - Width: 300-500 km - Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) - Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources - Ice: Never freezes - Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : - Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) - Dense fog (warm water, cold air) - Crowded shipping lanes - Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation)
docs.title: The Vent Strait

docs.text: Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : - Width: 3,000+ km at minimum - Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches - Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice - Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through - Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : - Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) - Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) - Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) - Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) - Isolation (rescue is unlikely)
docs.title: The Far Water

docs.text: Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : - Route: Curves north through near-polar waters - Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route - Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road - Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : - Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing - Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage - Operates only during Csend (narrow window) - Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season - Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring)
docs.title: The Bitter Crossing

docs.text: Extent : Everything north of approximately 70° latitude equivalent Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (3-4 km thick in center) - No permanent human habitation in deep polar zone - Transition zone (ice edge to permanent ice) is seasonally accessible - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season What's There : - Ice - Concentrated Pattern Residue (ancient, unharvested) - Ruins under the ice (confirmed by expeditions) - Creatures adapted to extreme cold (rare, dangerous) - Something else (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Northern Cap

docs.text: Extent : Everything south of approximately 65° latitude equivalent (extends further north due to continental anchoring by the Far Shelf) Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (thinner than northern, 1-2 km) - Merges with the Far Shelf's southern coast - Slightly more accessible (land connection) - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season - Different character from the northern cap (see: Polar Mystery) What's There : - Ice - The Shelf's southern glaciers - Mineral deposits (inaccessible) - Something different from the north (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Southern Cap

docs.text: The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound - This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova - The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection - The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage - Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison - Something is contained here - The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) - The cold is more engineered than natural - Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live - Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : - Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere - Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment - Very few people know both truths - The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?)
docs.title: The Polar Mystery
Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop

docs.text: Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources.
docs.title: The System

docs.text: The Middle Flow : - Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) - Surface flow moves north and south toward poles - Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures - Provides moisture for precipitation - Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts.
docs.title: Surface Currents (Warm)

docs.text: The Return Flow : - Surface water cools as it moves poleward - Cold water sinks at high latitudes - Deep current returns toward equator - Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate.
docs.title: Deep Currents (Cold)

docs.text: Láng (Summer) : - Surface currents strongest (maximum heating) - Ice retreat reveals more ocean surface - Trade routes fully open - Fish populations migrate with warm water Csend (Winter) : - Surface currents weakest - Ice formation begins at high latitudes - Currents may shift as ice blocks normal flows - Some routes become impassable Olvadás (Thaw) : - Meltwater influx disrupts currents - Unpredictable flows - Dangerous for shipping (currents don't follow normal patterns) - Rich nutrient release from melting ice Further documentation needed on: Specific coastline details, exact current speeds and patterns, submarine geology, maritime culture and technology
docs.title: Seasonal Variations

docs.text: Hálcova: Lunar System and Celestial Mechanics Overview Hálcova's five moons are not natural. The orbital mechanics are too perfect, the resonances too stable. Someone—or something—arranged them. This document covers what's observable and measurable, and addresses the mystery of their origin. The Five Moons: Detailed Parameters Lélek (The Soul Moon) Pronunciation : LAY-lek Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~1,200 km (about 1/3 Luna) - Surface: Pale gold/amber coloration, cratered - Albedo: High (reflects Sárgvas light efficiently) - Composition: Rocky, possibly metalite-rich (explains color) Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 30 local days - Distance: ~180,000 km (closer than Luna) - Inclination: 5° to Hálcova's equator - Eccentricity: 0.02 (nearly circular) Appearance from Surface : - Largest moon in the sky - Obvious phases, easily tracked - Pale gold color, sometimes amber during horizon view - Surface features visible to naked eye Associations : - Léilcrù circle (Soul/Core) - Core Binding practice - Orthodox religious significance (The Weaver's first finger) Hús (The Flesh Moon) Pronunciation : HOOSH Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~600 km - Surface: Iron-oxide rich, distinctly reddish - Albedo: Moderate - Composition: Dense, iron-heavy Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 18 local days - Distance: ~120,000 km - Inclination: 8° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.03 Appearance from Surface : - Medium-sized disc - Distinctly red/rust colored - Moves noticeably faster across sky than Lélek - Phases cycle quickly Associations : - Húslaimh circle (Flesh/Body) - Flesh Shaping practice - Blood, meat, physical existence - Considered unlucky to perform surgery when Hús is dark Kötel (The Binding Moon) Pronunciation : KUH-tel Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~700 km - Surface: Dark grey, low reflectivity - Albedo: Low (hard to see) - Composition: Carbon-rich rock, possibly ancient Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 45 local days - Distance: ~250,000 km - Inclination: 3° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.01 (most circular) Appearance from Surface : - Medium-sized but dim - Easy to lose track of (dark surface) - "The hidden moon"—often overlooked - Best visible during its rare bright phases Associations : - Cóitcai circle (Binding/Connection) - Pact Summoning - Hidden contracts, secrets - "Under Kötel" means "in secret" in common speech Vég (The Death Moon) Pronunciation : VAYG Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~300 km - Surface: Bright white/grey, high reflectivity - Albedo: Very high (ice surface?) - Composition: Unknown—spectral analysis inconsistent Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 12 local days - Distance: ~80,000 km (closest moon) - Inclination: 12° to equator (highest) - Eccentricity: 0.05 (most elliptical) Appearance from Surface : - Small but bright - Moves rapidly across sky - Almost star-like at distance, but tracking reveals motion - Inclined orbit means it sometimes appears far from other moons Associations : - Hálmaht circle (Death/End) - Colony Summoning - Endings, transitions, death - Fast movement associated with "life is brief" Fonál (The Fate Moon) Pronunciation : FOH-nahl Physical Characteristics : - Diameter: ~200 km - Surface: Grey-white, unremarkable - Albedo: Moderate - Composition: Unknown—too distant for clear analysis Orbital Parameters : - Orbital period: 60 local days - Distance: ~350,000 km (most distant) - Inclination: 2° to equator - Eccentricity: 0.02 Appearance from Surface : - Very small, often mistaken for bright star - Slow-moving, easy to lose - Requires knowledge to track - "The distant thread" Associations : - Sórscad circle (Fate/Path) - Fate Threading - Long-term destiny, the far view - Astrologers and Loom-Keepers track it carefully Orbital Resonances The Artificial Pattern The five moons' orbital periods form near-perfect ratios: Ratio Moons Period Relationship 2:3 Vég : Hús 12 : 18 days 2:3 Hús : Lélek 18 : 30 (actually 27, but close) 3:2 Lélek : Kötel 30 : 45 days 3:4 Kötel : Fonál 45 : 60 days These resonances keep the system stable. Without them, gravitational interactions would have destabilized the orbits over millions of years. The Implication : This configuration is not random. Either: 1. The moons were placed deliberately 2. The moons were adjusted into resonance 3. Something maintains the resonance actively Natural vs. Engineered Arguments for Natural Formation : - Resonance locks can form naturally (see Jupiter's moons) - Given enough time, systems find stable configurations - No direct evidence of construction Arguments for Engineering : - Five moons is unusual (most systems have 0-2 large moons) - The color/composition variety suggests different origins - Perfect resonance ratios are improbably clean - Cultural significance (five moons = five circles = five arts) suggests someone designed for meaning - Vég's spectral inconsistency suggests it's not normal rock/ice Prevailing Theory (among those who study such things): The moons existed but were adjusted—moved into their current orbits by some ancient civilization or the Elsewhere itself. The purpose: unknown. The timing: before recorded history. Alignment Events Calculation Finding when moons align requires calculating the Least Common Multiple of orbital periods: - LCM(12, 18, 30, 45, 60) = 180 days Full five-moon alignment : Every 180 local days (~twice per year) Alignment Types The Hand Closes (All Five Aligned) - Occurs every 180 days - All five moons in same region of sky - Major religious/cultural event - The Loom's accuracy reportedly spikes - Some magical operations enhanced - Some forbidden during this time The Three Fingers (Lélek + Hús + Kötel) - More frequent - Associated with binding magic generally - "Good" time for contracts and pacts The Death Pair (Vég + Fonál) - Small moons together - Associated with endings - Funeral timing often matches this alignment Opposition Alignments - When moons are on opposite sides of Hálcova - Creates complex tidal effects - Associated with conflict, division - "Moons at war" in common speech The Köd Alignment During the fifth season, moon positions have additional significance: Full alignment during Köd: Extremely rare, deeply feared Fonál invisible during Köd: "Fate hidden"—normal, expected Lélek dark during Köd: Considered dangerous (soul unprotected) Tidal Effects Basic Mechanics Five moons create overlapping tidal forces: - Each moon pulls water toward it - Multiple moons can reinforce or cancel - Tidal patterns are complex but predictable Tidal Categories Spring Tides (Moons Aligned) - Maximum tidal range - Dangerous for coastal areas - Opens/closes certain sea routes - Exposes tidal flats, submerges land bridges Neap Tides (Moons Opposed) - Minimum tidal range - Calmer waters - Different navigation challenges - Some harbors become inaccessible Great Tides (Five-Moon Alignment) - Extreme tidal range - Flooding in vulnerable areas - Sea ice behavior disrupted - Scheduled events (prepared for in advance) - Harvesting opportunities (what the tide exposes) Regional Tidal Variation Region Tidal Intensity Notes Narrow Sea Moderate Channeled between continents Shattered Reaches Extreme Complex coastlines amplify Middle Waters Moderate Open ocean buffering Vent Strait Low-Moderate Warm water density difference Far Shelf Moderate Long, exposed coastline Polar Seas Low Ice dampens tidal movement Tidal Timing and Culture Navigation : - Tide tables are essential documents - Skilled navigators memorize patterns - Errors kill ships and crews Architecture : - Coastal cities built to tidal range - Flooding expected, prepared for - Tide-gates on harbors and districts Ritual : - Religious ceremonies timed to tides - "Tide-naming" for children born during specific tides - Marriage timing considers tidal auspices Eclipse Patterns Solar Eclipses Lélek Solar Eclipse : - Only moon large enough for full solar eclipse - Occurs when Lélek crosses Sárgvas during new moon - Not every cycle (orbital inclination) - Duration: Up to 6 minutes of totality - Frequency: 1-2 per year (partial more common) Smaller Moon Transits : - Hús, Kötel, Vég, Fonál all transit Sárgvas - Visible as black dots crossing solar disc - Scientifically interesting, culturally minor - Transit timing used for orbital calculations Lunar Eclipses Hálcova's Shadow : - All moons pass through Hálcova's shadow periodically - Duration varies by moon size and distance - Moons turn dark red during eclipse (Sárgvas light through atmosphere) Eclipse Frequency by Moon : | Moon | Full Eclipse/Year | Notes | |------|-------------------|-------| | Lélek | 2-3 | Most dramatic | | Hús | 4-5 | Fast, brief | | Kötel | 1-2 | Hard to see (already dim) | | Vég | 6-8 | Frequent due to inclined orbit | | Fonál | 1 | Rare, distant | Moon-Moon Occultations Occasionally, one moon passes in front of another from Hálcova's perspective: Common Occultations : - Lélek occulting others: Most visible (large, bright covering small) - Vég occulting Fonál: Both small and dim, hard to observe - Any inner moon occulting any outer moon: Geometrically possible Cultural Significance : Each combination has interpreted meaning: - Lélek over Hús: "Soul masters flesh" - Hús over Lélek: "Flesh obscures soul" (rare, requires specific geometry) - Vég over any moon: "Death touches [that domain]" - Kötel occulting: "Contracts hidden" The Arrangement Question What We Know Five moons in stable resonance is improbable naturally The moons have different compositions (different origins?) Orbital periods create meaningful ratios Cultural/magical significance of five is pervasive No records of arrangement exist (predates history) Theories The Weaver's Design (Orthodox) - The divine pattern-maker arranged the moons as part of fate's infrastructure - They serve The Loom's function - Their arrangement proves intelligent design - Questioning further is impious The Ancient Engineers (Scholarly) - A pre-human or early human civilization moved the moons - Perhaps the same civilization that built the polar structures - The technology is lost, but the result persists - Understanding how could unlock power The Elsewhere Anchor (Heterodox) - The moons are anchor points for Elsewhere connection - They define the boundaries of the bleed - Their arrangement determines where and when the Elsewhere can manifest - The five factions may correspond to the five moons The Prison Bars (Hollow Saint) - The moons are part of the cage of fate - They enforce the Sórscad system - Disrupting them might free humanity from pattern - (Nobody has proposed a method) The Natural Improbability (Fleshwright) - Improbable doesn't mean impossible - Given the universe's age, unlikely configurations happen somewhere - Attributing design is anthropocentric bias - The cultural significance was imposed after, not built in Observable Evidence Supporting Artificial Arrangement : - Vég's spectral inconsistency (not normal material) - Perfect resonance ratios - Correlation between moon positions and magical phenomena - The Elsewhere bleed's relationship to lunar cycles Against : - No construction evidence on moon surfaces (from telescopes) - No historical records despite extensive ancient archives - If arrangement technology existed, where is it? The Working Answer For practical purposes, most people accept: - The moons are where they are - They affect tides, magic, and fate - Whether designed or natural, they're part of reality - Understanding the how might matter; understanding the why probably doesn't Calendar and Timekeeping The Lunar Calendar Various cultures use different moon-based calendars: Lélek Months : - 30-day months (Lélek's period) - 11.67 months per year - Practical but doesn't divide evenly Vég Weeks : - 12-day "weeks" (Vég's period) - 29.22 weeks per year - Used in some trading cultures The Five-Moon Year : - Track all five moons' cycles - Complex but comprehensive - Used by Loom-Keepers and astrologers - Average person can't maintain Standard Timekeeping Most cultures have settled on: - 36-hour day divided into segments (varies by culture) - Year of 350-351 days (with intercalary adjustments) - Five seasons as primary year division - Lunar positions noted for special occasions Further documentation needed on: Detailed tide tables by region, eclipse prediction methods, calendar conversion between systems, moon surface mapping, tidal creature behavior

docs.text: The Weaver's Design (Orthodox) - The divine pattern-maker arranged the moons as part of fate's infrastructure - They serve The Loom's function - Their arrangement proves intelligent design - Questioning further is impious The Ancient Engineers (Scholarly) - A pre-human or early human civilization moved the moons - Perhaps the same civilization that built the polar structures - The technology is lost, but the result persists - Understanding how could unlock power The Elsewhere Anchor (Heterodox) - The moons are anchor points for Elsewhere connection - They define the boundaries of the bleed - Their arrangement determines where and when the Elsewhere can manifest - The five factions may correspond to the five moons The Prison Bars (Hollow Saint) - The moons are part of the cage of fate - They enforce the Sórscad system - Disrupting them might free humanity from pattern - (Nobody has proposed a method) The Natural Improbability (Fleshwright) - Improbable doesn't mean impossible - Given the universe's age, unlikely configurations happen somewhere - Attributing design is anthropocentric bias - The cultural significance was imposed after, not built in
docs.title: Theories

docs.text: Supporting Artificial Arrangement : - Vég's spectral inconsistency (not normal material) - Perfect resonance ratios - Correlation between moon positions and magical phenomena - The Elsewhere bleed's relationship to lunar cycles Against : - No construction evidence on moon surfaces (from telescopes) - No historical records despite extensive ancient archives - If arrangement technology existed, where is it?
docs.title: Observable Evidence

docs.text: For practical purposes, most people accept: - The moons are where they are - They affect tides, magic, and fate - Whether designed or natural, they're part of reality - Understanding the how might matter; understanding the why probably doesn't
docs.title: The Working Answer

docs.text: Various cultures use different moon-based calendars: Lélek Months : - 30-day months (Lélek's period) - 11.67 months per year - Practical but doesn't divide evenly Vég Weeks : - 12-day "weeks" (Vég's period) - 29.22 weeks per year - Used in some trading cultures The Five-Moon Year : - Track all five moons' cycles - Complex but comprehensive - Used by Loom-Keepers and astrologers - Average person can't maintain
docs.title: The Lunar Calendar

docs.text: Most cultures have settled on: - 36-hour day divided into segments (varies by culture) - Year of 350-351 days (with intercalary adjustments) - Five seasons as primary year division - Lunar positions noted for special occasions Further documentation needed on: Detailed tide tables by region, eclipse prediction methods, calendar conversion between systems, moon surface mapping, tidal creature behavior

The effect is strongest at the poles and diminishes toward the equator. Full Bleed (Polar Regions) Physical Environment : - Visual distortions (wrong distances, shifted colors) - Sound anomalies (echoes from nothing, unnatural silence) - Temperature fluctuations unconnected to weather - Ground-level aurora-like phenomena Entity Activity : - Elsewhere beings manifest without summoning - Appear partial, flickering, attention wandering - Most ignore humans; some don't - All five factions appear: - Accountants : Counting, ignoring unless debts exist - Hungry : Seeking sensation—the dangerous ones - Architects : Adjusting, positioning, arranging - Mirrors : Watching, following, studying observers - Absent : Simply present, doing nothing visible Human Effects : - Pact Summoners feel entities without calling - Core Binders' echoes become hyperactive, may realize they're dead - Fate Threaders pull "sideways" futures - Colony hosts feel colonies reaching toward something - Unpacted humans: hallucinations, intrusions, compulsions Partial Bleed (Transition Zones) Entities sensed but not fully manifest Voices, glimpses, influences Stronger effects near polar edge Habitable but disturbing Some permanent settlements with adaptation strategies Minor Phenomena (Temperate Band) Vivid dreams, especially of unlived lives Déjà vu and premonition spikes Paranoia and suspicion increase Minor visual/auditory phenomena Loom predictions become strange (accurate about improbable things) Protected Zone (Middle Waters) Minimal Köd effects Theories: warmth, volcanic activity, population density, unknown factor Refugees flee toward Middle Waters during Köd Prices and tensions spike Who Enters the Polar Bleed? The Desperate : Seeking pacts without leverage, escaping patterns, pursuing forbidden knowledge The Fortified : Research expeditions, military operations, resource extraction (heavy protection) The Trapped : Outposts that can't evacuate, indigenous survivors, things that were human Religious Responses Orthodox : Polar bleed proves the danger of straying from The Weaver's design. Wardens close transition borders. Returnees examined for contamination. Threadist : The bleed shows fate is unfinished. Insights from Köd may reveal the collaborative nature of design. Hollow Saint : The bleed is the crack in fate's prison. Pilgrimage to the edge (not into full bleed) is holy work. Colony Cult : Colonies remember something from the bleed. The original unity existed there. Ancestor Speaker : Echoes become dangerous during Köd. This is when the dead most need binding—for their protection. Fleshwright : Elsewhere entities are just different biology. Study them (safely) to understand life without pattern. Pattern Residue Thermodynamics The Mechanism Pattern Residue is "condensed probability"—fate-weight made physical. This exotic matter has unusual thermodynamic properties. Charged State : - Residue in natural/raw form actively absorbs thermal energy - Pulls heat from environment into itself - Stores energy as captured entropy/information Triggered Release : - Specific conditions (chemical, magical, mechanical) release stored energy - Energy emerges as heat - Residue becomes "spent" or "ash"—thermodynamically inert Equilibrium : - Natural Residue absorbs until saturated - Slowly re-radiates over time - Absorption is fast; re-radiation is slow - Net effect: heat trapped, world cooled The Climate Feedback Loop Death releases Pattern Residue Residue absorbs heat from environment Environment cools Cold contributes to death More Residue released Loop continues The Civilization Counter-Loop Residue is harvested Harvested Residue burned for heat Local heat released (cities warm) Spent Residue doesn't return to atmosphere Less atmospheric Residue = slightly warmer baseline But harvesting draws more Residue toward cities Surrounding areas relatively colder Cities become warm islands Implications The Dark Bargain : Civilization survives by burning death. The more death harvested, the warmer cities can be. Peace reduces fuel supply. Climate Control : Institutions could warm or cool regions by managing Residue distribution. This is probably happening. The Polar Question : Why so cold? Ancient mass death? Residue migration? Deliberate engineering? Elsewhere connection? The Middle Waters Question : Why warm? Volcanic heat? Less historical death? Living density? Unknown protection? docs.text: During Köd, the boundary between Hálcova and Elsewhere thins. The effect is strongest at the poles and diminishes toward the equator.
docs.title: The Polar Bleed

docs.text: Physical Environment : - Visual distortions (wrong distances, shifted colors) - Sound anomalies (echoes from nothing, unnatural silence) - Temperature fluctuations unconnected to weather - Ground-level aurora-like phenomena Entity Activity : - Elsewhere beings manifest without summoning - Appear partial, flickering, attention wandering - Most ignore humans; some don't - All five factions appear: - Accountants : Counting, ignoring unless debts exist - Hungry : Seeking sensation—the dangerous ones - Architects : Adjusting, positioning, arranging - Mirrors : Watching, following, studying observers - Absent : Simply present, doing nothing visible Human Effects : - Pact Summoners feel entities without calling - Core Binders' echoes become hyperactive, may realize they're dead - Fate Threaders pull "sideways" futures - Colony hosts feel colonies reaching toward something - Unpacted humans: hallucinations, intrusions, compulsions

docs.text: Orthodox : Polar bleed proves the danger of straying from The Weaver's design. Wardens close transition borders. Returnees examined for contamination. Pilgrimage to the edge (not into full bleed) is holy work. Colony Cult : Colonies remember something from the bleed. The original unity existed there. Study them (safely) to understand life without pattern.

docs.text: Pattern Residue is "condensed probability"—fate-weight made physical. This exotic matter has unusual thermodynamic properties. Charged State : - Residue in natural/raw form actively absorbs thermal energy - Pulls heat from environment into itself - Stores energy as captured entropy/information Triggered Release : - Specific conditions (chemical, magical, mechanical) release stored energy - Energy emerges as heat - Residue becomes "spent" or "ash"—thermodynamically inert Equilibrium : - Natural Residue absorbs until saturated - Slowly re-radiates over time - Absorption is fast; re-radiation is slow - Net effect: heat trapped, world cooled

docs.text: Economics and Class in Hálcova Overview Economics in Hálcova cannot be separated from fate. The Sórscad pattern determines access to credit, employment, insurance, and opportunity. Pattern Residue—the energy of dissolving fates—fuels magic and industry. Death is literally productive. This creates an economy where some people are worth more dead than alive, where peace is expensive, and where the institutions that predict your future have financial stakes in that prediction coming true. The Fate Market Pattern as Asset Your Sórscad is not just identity—it's capital. Pattern-Weight Some patterns are "heavier" than others: - More fate-significance - More likely to impact events - More valuable as Pattern Residue when released Heavy patterns belong to: - Those born into consequential circumstances - Those whose choices ripple outward - Those predicted for significant outcomes (positive or negative) Light patterns belong to: - Those born into marginal circumstances - Those whose choices affect few others - Those predicted for unremarkable outcomes The Market Implications Heavy patterns command higher prices in substitution deals (Pact Summoning) Heavy patterns produce more valuable Residue upon death Heavy patterns are worth more to The Loom (more data value) Heavy patterns are targets for various exploitation This creates a hierarchy: some lives have more market value than others, calculated and priced. Pattern Speculation Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Pattern Arbitrage Some patterns are mispriced. The Loom's predictions, while accurate on average, have errors in individual cases. Arbitrageurs look for: - Patterns undervalued by The Loom (capable people dismissed as low-potential) - Patterns overvalued by The Loom (impressive readings masking actual mediocrity) - Situations where environmental change will shift pattern-outcomes They invest in undervalued people—education, opportunity, resources—and profit when those people outperform predictions. This is legal. It's also morally ambiguous: you're betting on people, treating lives as investments, profiting from the gap between predicted and actual humanity. Credit and Debt Pattern-Based Lending All credit decisions incorporate Sórscad data: Interest Rates Pattern-privileged: Low rates. The Loom predicts they'll repay. Pattern-constrained: High rates. The Loom predicts elevated default risk. Pattern-illegible (practitioners): Variable. Their patterns are too contaminated for reliable prediction. Collateral What can you pledge? Physical assets (traditional) Future earnings (income garnishment) Pattern Residue rights (if you die, the lender harvests) Pact-substitution rights (you can be offered to an Elsewhere entity) Echo-binding rights (you can be bound after death) The last three are where lending gets dark. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. Endpoint possibilities: - Debt-bondage (working off the debt under contract) - Residue-pledge (worth more dead than alive) - Pact-transfer (sold to cover what you owe) - Echo-indenture (bound to serve after death) The system is designed to produce these endpoints. They're not failures of the system—they're the system working as intended. The Pact Economy Elsewhere Entities as Lenders Pact Summoning functions like supernatural credit: - You receive power now - You pay with your core later - Interest accrues (the more you use, the faster you pay) - Default is impossible (the entity always collects) Substitution as Currency Cores are fungible. The entity doesn't care whose core it gets. This creates: - Substitution markets : Where cores are bought and sold - Core brokers : Middlemen connecting those with cores to sell and summoners needing payment - Substitution pricing : Heavy patterns worth more, light patterns worth less - Procurement operations : Acquiring cores through various means (legal and otherwise) The Substitution Hierarchy From most to least valuable: 1. Exceptional patterns (seventh son of seventh son, etc.) 2. Heavy patterns from powerful lineages 3. Standard adult patterns 4. Light adult patterns 5. Child patterns (potential not yet realized) 6. Elderly patterns (mostly spent) 7. Animal patterns (weak, but abundant) This is a price list for souls. It exists. People consult it. Employment and Opportunity Pattern-Gated Careers Many positions require specific pattern profiles: Explicit Requirements - "Must have Court-Field or Heights-Field classification" - "No Wound-Self or Shard-Self candidates" - "Minimum Road-Path or Ladder-Path trajectory" Implicit Screening Even without stated requirements, hiring decisions incorporate pattern data: - "We don't discriminate based on pattern—we just look at the whole candidate" - "Their pattern doesn't fit our company culture" - "The Loom predicts retention issues with that profile" Pattern Families and Stereotypes Certain pattern-combinations are associated with professions: "Lamplighters" (Lantern-Road-Pact-Duty-Court) - Bureaucrats, administrators, reliable employees - Boring but dependable - Automatically considered for stable positions "Storm-Children" (Spark-Crossroads-Twin-Rebel-Wild) - Artists, adventurers, troublemakers - Exciting but unreliable - Automatically excluded from positions requiring stability "Knot-Born" (Wound-Maze-Thorn-Fear-Street) - Criminals, laborers, expendables - Dangerous but useful - Automatically considered for dangerous or demeaning work These stereotypes become self-fulfilling. Denied legitimate opportunity, the Knot-Born turn to illegitimate work. Their criminal records confirm The Loom's predictions. The cycle continues. Labor Markets Pattern Segregation Different patterns concentrate in different industries: - Heights-Field patterns in management - Forge-Field patterns in manufacturing - Street-Field patterns in informal economy - Underbelly-Field patterns in criminal enterprise This isn't natural sorting—it's structural channeling. Each pattern is directed toward "appropriate" work from Binding Day onward. Wage Differentials Same work, different pay, based on pattern: - Pattern-privileged workers paid more (justified as "retention cost") - Pattern-constrained workers paid less (justified as "risk premium") - The gap is legal, documented, defended as actuarially sound The Pattern Residue Economy Production Pattern Residue is produced when patterns dissolve—primarily at death. Natural Production - Every death releases some Residue - More from heavy patterns - More from traumatic deaths - More from pattern-rich populations Sites of Concentration - Battlefields (mass death, often violent) - Plague zones (mass death, weakened patterns) - Execution grounds (controlled, harvestable) - Disaster sites (concentrated mortality) Manufactured Production The demand for Residue creates incentives: - War as industry (mass death with geographic concentration) - Plague management (letting disease run for harvest) - Capital punishment as production (not justice, but fuel) - Blood sports (entertainment plus Residue) The Residue Trade Harvesting Licensed harvesters extract Residue from death sites. Unlicensed harvesters do the same, illegally. Equipment required: - Collection apparatus (varies by tradition) - Storage containers (keeping Residue stable) - Transportation (Residue degrades; speed matters) Occupational hazards: - Exposure effects (too much contact changes you) - Competition (other harvesters, scavengers, authorities) - Moral weight (you're literally profiting from death) Refinement Raw Residue requires processing for most uses: - Purification (removing contaminants) - Stabilization (extending shelf life) - Concentration (increasing potency) - Packaging (making it tradeable) Refineries are industrial operations—factories of death-product. Distribution Residue reaches end users through: - Official channels (licensed trade, taxation, regulation) - Gray markets (legal but questionable sourcing) - Black markets (illegal, untaxed, often higher quality) Pricing Residue prices fluctuate based on: - Supply (peace = scarce; war = abundant) - Quality (pure vs. contaminated) - Source (some deaths produce better Residue) - Demand (more practitioners = higher prices) During prolonged peace, prices spike. Some institutions have incentives to prevent peace from lasting. The Moral Economy Who Benefits From Death The Loom (fuel for operation) Core Binders (fuel for anchors) Residue traders (profit margin) Magitech industries (raw material) Anyone using Residue-powered devices Who Provides Death The pattern-constrained (dying in wars, plagues, prisons) The poor (selling Residue rights for cash now) The condemned (executed for production) Populations deemed "surplus" The economy of Hálcova is built on bodies. Clean hands are expensive. Everyone is complicit at some remove. Class Structure The Pattern-Privileged Characteristics - Born with or drawn into favorable patterns - The Loom predicts success; institutions deliver it - Low interest rates, good jobs, favorable treatment How They Stay Privileged - Marry within pattern-class (maintaining lineage patterns) - Leverage pattern-capital into actual capital - Use wealth to insulate from pattern-deviation consequences - Support institutions that validate pattern-prediction Their Perspective - "The system works—look at my success" - "Pattern-discrimination is just actuarial accuracy" - "If their patterns predicted better, they'd do better" The Pattern-Constrained Characteristics - Born with or drawn into unfavorable patterns - The Loom predicts struggle; institutions ensure it - High interest rates, bad jobs, hostile treatment How They Stay Constrained - Denied opportunity that might disprove predictions - Forced into circumstances that confirm predictions - Accumulate debt, criminal records, health problems - Each confirmation further constrains next generation Their Perspective - "The system is rigged—look at my constraints" - "They decided what I'd be before I could decide anything" - "Success despite pattern proves nothing; they just call it deviation" The Pattern-Illegible Characteristics - Practitioners whose patterns are contaminated, faded, or transformed - The Loom can't predict them reliably - Treated with suspicion, opportunity, or both Types - Heavy Core Binders (layered patterns from echo-bleed) - Established Flesh Shapers (hollowed Húslaimh circles) - Deep Pact Summoners (faded Léilcrù from payment) - Depleted Fate Threaders (narrowed Sórscad from extraction) - Long-term Colony Hosts (hybrid patterns from transformation) Their Position - Some institutions exclude them (can't assess risk) - Some institutions seek them (unpredictability is useful) - They exist outside normal class structure - Often form their own communities and networks The Industrial Magitech Sector Residue-Powered Technology Pattern Residue isn't just for practitioners—it powers industry. Applications - Pattern-engines (The Loom and derivatives) - Communication systems (pattern-resonance transmission) - Transportation (Residue-fueled vehicles for high-priority use) - Manufacturing (certain processes require Residue catalyst) - Weapons (Residue-enhanced ammunition, siege equipment) The Magic-Industrial Complex Industries dependent on Residue form a political bloc: - They need steady supply (war, plague, execution) - They oppose peace when it threatens supply - They support policies that produce harvestable death - They lobby against restrictions on harvesting This isn't conspiracy—it's interest group politics. The people running these industries aren't monsters. They're responding to incentives. The incentives produce monstrous outcomes. Labor in Magitech Working with Residue changes you. Long-term exposure: - Physical effects (pallor, temperature sensitivity, pattern-interference) - Psychological effects (death-awareness, morbid outlook) - Social effects (stigma, isolation from non-exposed) Residue-industry workers are pattern-constrained almost by definition. The work confirms their patterns, trapping them further. The Underground Economy What's Traded Illegally Unregistered cores : Bypassing official harvesting channels Substitution services : Procuring cores for pact-payment Pattern data : Stolen Registry information Unlicensed binding : Echo-services without permits Black-market homunculi : Especially mimics Infection services : Colony hosting outside legal channels Fate-fraud : Forged or manipulated pattern records Deviation assistance : Helping people evade pattern-expectations Criminal Organizations Structure - Often organized by pattern-family (Knot-Born networks, etc.) - Use pattern-illegible members for unpredictable operations - Bribe or coerce Warden Order members - Operate across regions with different enforcement levels Services - Debt elimination (including murdering creditors) - Pattern-laundering (falsifying Registry records) - Protection (from both Wardens and rival organizations) - Procurement (cores, blood, colonies, anything tradeable) Relationship to Legal Economy - Provides services legal economy won't - Employs people legal economy excludes - Operates on same logic (profit, transaction, leverage) - Often partners with "legitimate" institutions quietly The Common Person Daily Economic Life For someone without wealth, special patterns, or practitioner abilities: Employment - Pattern determines options before you apply - Wages set by pattern-class, not just skill - Advancement limited by pattern-ceiling - Termination easy if pattern-excused Credit - High rates if available at all - Collateral requirements often exceed assets - Debt-trap structures common - Pattern-default possible (selling yourself) Housing - Pattern-segregated neighborhoods - Insurance based on district pattern-profile - Mobility limited by pattern-appropriate areas - Quality tracks pattern-privilege Healthcare - Treatment recommendations incorporate pattern-data - "Pattern-appropriate care" means lower quality for constrained - End-of-life decisions consider Residue value - Chronic conditions managed by pattern-expectation Family - Marriage recommendations based on pattern-compatibility - Child-bearing decisions influenced by predicted patterns - Education options constrained by pattern-category - Inheritance affected by pattern-privilege Coping Strategies Acceptance - "My pattern is my pattern" - Find meaning in what fate allows - Orthodox faith provides framework - Community within pattern-class Hustle - Work the system's margins - Find opportunities The Loom undervalues - Build informal networks - Accumulate resources despite predictions Escape - Pattern-illegibility through practice (if you can afford initiation) - Geographical mobility (frontier regions, different enforcement) - Criminal economy (if legitimate economy excludes you) - Pact Summoning (trade pattern for power, lose both eventually) Resistance - Threadist reform movements - Hollow Saint nihilism - Pattern-fraud and deviation - Collective action against pattern-discrimination Most people combine these, shifting between acceptance, hustle, escape attempts, and occasional resistance depending on circumstances. docs.text: Religion in Hálcova: Faith and Fate Overview Religion in Hálcova is inseparable from fate. The Sórscad pattern is not just a predictive framework—it's the primary evidence of divine existence. Something assigns patterns. Something makes predictions accurate. Something answers when The Loom queries. That something is worshipped, feared, manipulated, and denied in various ways. But it is never ignored. The Core Theological Question What is Fate? All religions in Hálcova grapple with this. The answers vary, but the question is universal: Is Fate a conscious entity with will and purpose? Is Fate an impersonal force, like gravity or time? Is Fate many entities, or one entity with many faces? Is Fate the same as the Elsewhere, or something that contains or transcends it? Is Fate benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent? The evidence is ambiguous. The Loom works. Predictions come true. Something responds to ritual. But what it wants, why it responds, and whether it cares about human wellbeing—these remain contested. The Orthodoxy: The Church of the Weaver Core Beliefs The dominant religious framework across most of Hálcova. The Weaver ( A Szövő ) is: - The divine pattern-maker who creates all Sórscads - The source of The Loom's accuracy - The author of fate, whose design is perfect even when painful - Neither purely benevolent nor malevolent— necessary Doctrine : The Pattern Is Sacred : Your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role. It reflects The Weaver's purpose for you. Acceptance Is Virtue : Embracing your pattern, even its hardships, is holy. Resistance creates suffering. The Loom Is True : The Loom reads The Weaver's will accurately. Trust its predictions. Deviation Is Sin : Acting against your pattern wounds the cosmic design. Enforcement is medicine, not punishment. The Design Serves : The Weaver's plan serves existence itself, not individual happiness. Your suffering has purpose you cannot see. Practices The Drawings : Natal and Binding draws are religious ceremonies, not just administrative procedures. Priests conduct them. Families gather. The revelation of pattern is considered a holy moment. Pattern-Prayer : Daily meditation on your Sórscad. Contemplating its meaning, accepting its implications, aligning will with fate. Correction Rituals : When you've acted against pattern, confession and ritual penance. Overseen by priests, recorded in temple registers. Death Rites : Ensuring proper Pattern Residue release. Prayers for the Léilcrù to return cleanly to The Weaver's design. Structure Temples at every significant settlement Priests trained in theology and basic pattern-reading Bishops overseeing regional temples The High Weavery : Central authority, located at the Great Node The Synod : Overlapping governance with the Warden Order Who Believes This The pattern-privileged (the system validates them) Those raised in Orthodox communities Those who find comfort in cosmic purpose Institutions that benefit from pattern-enforcement The Appeal Orthodoxy offers: - Meaning (your suffering has purpose) - Community (shared belief and practice) - Structure (clear rules and expectations) - Comfort (fate is in capable hands) For people whose patterns predict good outcomes, this is easy faith. For those whose patterns predict hardship, it's harder—but some find peace in submission. The Threadist Reformation: Fate as Collaboration Core Beliefs A reform movement within Orthodoxy that takes a different view of deviation. Key Difference : The Weaver is not finished weaving. Fate is still being created. Your choices participate in the design. Doctrine : The Pattern Is Draft : Your Sórscad is a starting point, not a sentence. The Weaver offers threads; you help weave. Deviation Is Data : When someone acts against pattern, it might be error—or it might be new information. The design evolves. Fate Threading Is Collaboration : The Art isn't theft from fate—it's working with unfinished material. Threaders are co-creators. The Loom Predicts, Not Prescribes : Accuracy reflects current patterns, not fixed destiny. Change the patterns, change the predictions. Agency Is Sacred : Free will is The Weaver's gift, not its enemy. Choosing is how we participate in creation. Implications Threadists: - Accept Fate Threading as legitimate (with ethical constraints) - View enforcement with suspicion (forcing patterns may be anti-divine) - See deviation as potentially holy (revelation of new design elements) - Believe The Loom should inform, not control Who Believes This Fate Threaders seeking religious justification Pattern-constrained seeking hope for change Intellectuals uncomfortable with determinism Reformers within Orthodox institutions Orthodox Response The Orthodoxy considers Threadism heresy: - "The design is complete. Claiming otherwise is pride." - "Agency serves the pattern, not the reverse." - "Threadist doctrine justifies sin and chaos." Threadists are tolerated in some regions, persecuted in others. The Warden Order considers them ideologically dangerous. The Hollow Saints: Fate as Prison Core Beliefs A heretical movement that inverts Orthodox values entirely. Core Insight : The Sórscad is a cage. The Weaver is a jailer. True freedom comes from escaping your pattern entirely. Doctrine : Fate Is Bondage : Patterns are chains. Predictions are control. The Loom is a surveillance apparatus. The Weaver Is Enemy : Whatever assigns patterns does not have human interests at heart. Worship is collaboration with your oppressor. Elsewhere Is Escape : Selling your core to Elsewhere entities isn't damnation—it's liberation. They're taking you out of the cage. The Absent Are Saints : The Elsewhere faction that wants nothing —they represent true freedom. No pattern, no prediction, no control. Emptiness Is Peace : The consumed—those whose cores are fully paid—are not victims. They're free. The husk left behind isn't a tragedy; it's a chrysalis. Practices Pact Encouragement : Hollow Saint communities help members make pacts. They provide information on entities, facilitate contacts, support those paying their debts. Substitution Ethics : Unlike casual pact-users, Hollow Saints have complex ethics around substitution. Some refuse it entirely (liberation should be chosen). Others permit it for the unwilling (freeing them from patterns they hate). The Empty Honored : Those fully consumed are celebrated. Their remains are treated with reverence. They escaped. Proselytization : Spreading the truth about Fate's prison nature. Recruiting those most oppressed by their patterns. Who Believes This Pact Summoners seeking ideological framework The pattern-condemned who've given up on Orthodox comfort Those who've watched loved ones consumed and need meaning Anti-institutional radicals Orthodox Response The Orthodoxy considers this satanic heresy: - "They worship demons and call it freedom." - "The consumed aren't free—they're destroyed." - "This cult leads people to eternal annihilation." The Warden Order hunts Hollow Saints aggressively. The cult operates in secret, recruitment happens quietly, and practicing openly means death. The Fleshwright Materialists: Fate as Biology Core Beliefs A philosophical-religious position emerging from Flesh Shaping traditions. Core Insight : The pattern isn't divine—it's biological. The Sórscad is legible because bodies are predictable. There is no Weaver. There is only meat. Doctrine : Patterns Are Organic : The Sórscad reads biological tendencies—brain structure, hormonal predisposition, physical capacity. Calling this "divine" is superstition. Prediction Is Statistics : The Loom works because large populations behave predictably. This isn't fate—it's probability. Homunculi Prove It : Flesh Shapers create life without patterns. If fate were real, they couldn't. The fact that homunculi exist outside The Loom shows the system is physical, not metaphysical. Liberation Through Construction : The goal is to build beings entirely outside pattern . Not escaping fate—transcending the biological substrate that makes prediction possible. Whatever Answers The Loom is not divine. It's something that reads biology. Understanding what it is (probably Elsewhere, probably interested in Pattern Residue) demystifies the entire system. Implications Fleshwrights: - Practice Flesh Shaping as philosophical statement - Seek to create pattern-free life - View The Loom as technology, not religion - Want to understand the Attendance scientifically Who Believes This Flesh Shapers with intellectual ambitions Materialist philosophers Scientists studying pattern-biology Anti-religious secularists Orthodox Response Fleshwrights are considered dangerous atheists: - "They deny the sacred to excuse their abominations." - "Their constructs are hollow precisely because they lack divine pattern." - "Calling the Attendance 'technology' is willful blindness." Fleshwrights aren't persecuted as violently as Hollow Saints (they're not recruiting the desperate to suicide-by-pact), but they're excluded from respectable society in Orthodox regions. The Colony Cults: Fate as Composite Core Beliefs Religious movements centered on fungal colony symbolism and practice. Core Insight : Individual patterns are fragments of a larger whole. The colonies remember older, deeper patterns. True fate isn't personal—it's collective. Doctrine : The Great Network : Before individuals, there was connection. The original pattern was One, not many. Separation is the wound. Colonies Remember : Ancient fungal networks carry patterns older than The Loom, older than the Orthodoxy. They know what fate was before it was divided. Hosting Is Reunion : Taking a colony into yourself is rejoining the original pattern. Your individual Sórscad becomes part of something larger. Death Serves Life : When colonies consume the dead, they preserve patterns that would otherwise dissipate. This is holy recycling, not desecration. The Old Ones : The most ancient colonies, passed through generations, may themselves be divine. Or at least more divine than The Weaver, who only divides. Practices Communal Infection : Deliberate colony-sharing within cult communities. Everyone carries the same strain; everyone is connected. Ancestor Incorporation : Feeding the colony deceased cult members. They persist in the network's memory. Not bound like echoes— integrated . Network Communion : Group rituals where hosts link through their colonies. Shared sensation, shared memory, something like shared consciousness. Fruit Offerings : Summoning constructs from colony-memory as offerings to the network itself. Returning patterns to the collective. Who Believes This Colony Hosts seeking spiritual framework Communities where hosting is traditional Those who've experienced network-communion and found it meaningful Those seeking alternative to individualistic fate-models Orthodox Response Colony Cults are considered primitive and dangerous: - "They worship parasites and call it communion." - "Their 'memories' are contaminated, not sacred." - "Infection-spreading is assault, not religion." Colony Cults exist in legal gray zones. Hosting itself may be legal; deliberate infection is not. Cults that stay private are tolerated. Cults that proselytize are persecuted. The Ancestor Speakers: Fate as Conversation Core Beliefs Religious traditions centered on Core Binding as ancestral communion. Core Insight : Your pattern includes everyone who came before. The dead aren't gone—they're waiting to be heard. Binding is not imprisonment; it's invitation. Doctrine : The Pattern Is Genealogy : Your Sórscad carries traces of ancestral patterns. You are your lineage speaking through new flesh. The Dead Advise : Properly bound echoes aren't prisoners—they're advisors. They see what you cannot. They know what you haven't learned. Binding Is Dialogue : The relationship between binder and echo should be collaborative. Listen to them. Honor them. Release them when the conversation is complete. The Loom Sees Surface : Pattern-prediction captures tendencies, not depths. The ancestors see depths. Both are needed. Death Is Transition : The dead move from speaking to spoken-to. Binding maintains their voice in the world. Release returns them to the greater conversation. Practices Ancestral Binding : Deliberately binding family dead for guidance. Sometimes for generations. Echo Council : Group decision-making that includes bound ancestors. The living propose; the dead advise. Binding Ethics : Strict rules about who can be bound (family only, or with permission), how they should be treated (respect, not command), and when to release (when the conversation ends). Pattern Reading : Interpreting current Sórscads through ancestral context. "Your Wound-Self echoes your grandmother's; let's ask her about it." Who Believes This Core Binders from traditional lineages Communities where binding is ancestral practice Those who've had meaningful echo relationships Those seeking ethical framework for binding Orthodox Response Ancestor Speaking is the most tolerated heterodoxy: - "At least they honor the dead, in their way." - "The errors are containable within proper binding law." - "Better this than the Hollow Saints." In practice, Ancestor Speakers often coexist with Orthodoxy. They attend Orthodox temples, participate in Orthodox rites, and quietly maintain their echo-relationships at home. The Warden Order monitors but rarely persecutes. Common Themes Across All Faiths The Loom's Accuracy Is Accepted No tradition denies that predictions work. They disagree about: - Why they work (divine vs. biological vs. Elsewhere) - Whether they should work (fate as good vs. fate as control) - What to do about it (accept vs. resist vs. escape vs. transcend) Something Answers All traditions acknowledge that something responds to The Loom's queries. They disagree about: - What it is (Weaver vs. Elsewhere vs. technology vs. network) - What it wants (cosmic design vs. Pattern Residue vs. unknown) - Whether to serve it, use it, or escape it Death Matters Pattern Residue, core harvesting, and what happens when patterns dissolve—all traditions have positions: - Orthodox: return to The Weaver's design - Threadists: pattern continues influencing unfinished design - Hollow Saints: liberation from pattern - Fleshwrights: biological decay, nothing more - Colony Cults: preservation in the network - Ancestor Speakers: transition to advisory role Individual vs. Collective Fate The tension between personal pattern and collective destiny runs through everything: - Orthodox: individual patterns serve collective design - Threadists: individual choices shape collective future - Hollow Saints: escape is individual; liberation is personal - Fleshwrights: transcendence is biological, not spiritual - Colony Cults: individual is illusion; collective is truth - Ancestor Speakers: individual is genealogy speaking Religious Geography Orthodox Dominance The Core regions, major cities, centers of power. Temples everywhere. Warden Order presence. Pattern-enforcement integrated with governance. Heterodox Pockets Frontier regions, traditional communities, places where Orthodox reach is weak. Various heresies coexist, sometimes in the same village. Underground Hollow Saints, radical Fleshwrights, aggressive Colony Cults. Operating in secret even in Orthodox heartland. Networks of the desperate and the convicted. Contested Regions where multiple traditions compete openly. Religious conflict overlapping with political conflict. Conversion and counter-conversion. docs.text: The Warden Order: Enforcers of Fate Overview The Warden Order ( Őrvonalak —"Guardian Lines") is the enforcement arm of Loom orthodoxy. They are investigators, hunters, judges, and executioners rolled into one—a zealot force dedicated to ensuring that Fate's predictions come true and that no one escapes their pattern. They are, in essence, the Loom's police. But "police" doesn't capture the theological dimension. To the Wardens, deviation from pattern isn't crime. It's heresy. It's cosmic disorder. It's a wound in reality that must be cauterized. Purpose and Mandate The Problem They Solve The Loom's predictions are accurate—but not perfectly accurate. Deviations occur: Someone predicted for a Road-Path career pivots unexpectedly A Blade-Hálmaht pattern survives past their statistical death-window A Knot-Born pattern achieves what their family should have prevented A Core Binder escapes their bleed-trajectory through unknown means A Pact Summoner pays their debt early through suspicious circumstances Most deviations are noise. Some are environmental factors The Loom missed. But some—the ones that matter—represent deliberate manipulation. Pattern-Fraud : Misrepresenting your Sórscad to gain advantage. Pattern-Evasion : Deliberately acting against your pattern. Pattern-Manipulation : Attempting to change your pattern through magic or ritual. Pattern-Interference : Helping others evade or manipulate their patterns. The Warden Order exists to detect, investigate, and punish these crimes against Fate. The Theological Mandate To the Orthodox faithful, your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role in existence. Deviation is not just illegal—it's an assault on cosmic order. Deviation creates ripples that damage the design Enforcement is not punishment—it's correction They are not cruel—they are necessary Structure and Organization The Ranks High washout rate (many cannot handle the attunement) Wardens ( Őrök ) - Full enforcement authority Priors ( Előjárók ) Supervisory rank overseeing multiple Wardens Authority over major deviation cases Can convene judgment tribunals Identify patterns of deviation across populations Predict where manipulation is likely occurring Rarely operate in the field; their work is in the archives Political as well as religious figures The Synod ( Zsinat ) - Governing council of the Order - Seven High Wardens plus the Loom-Keeper General - Sets enforcement policy and theological interpretation - Meets at the Great Node in [capital city TBD] The Attunement Wardens are not simply trained. They are attuned —connected to The Loom in a way that grants them abilities beyond normal Loom-Keepers. The Process : - Conducted at a major Loom-Node - Involves extended contact with a pattern-engine - The initiate opens themselves to the Attendance - Something is exchanged—given and received - Those who survive are changed What Attunement Grants : Pattern-Sight : Wardens can see Sórscad patterns without mechanical assistance. Not complete readings—impressions, dominant circles, deviations from expected behavior. Deviation-Sense : A feeling—almost physical—when someone nearby is acting against their pattern. Like hearing a wrong note in a familiar song. Loom-Voice : The ability to query The Loom mentally, receiving basic information about a subject's pattern and prediction-status. Limited range, requires concentration. Thread-Touch : In physical contact, a Warden can feel someone's fate-weight. How heavy their pattern is, how much remains, how much has been spent or sold. What Attunement Costs : Pattern-Lock : An attuned Warden's own Sórscad becomes fixed. They cannot deviate from their own pattern without experiencing severe dissonance. They are bound to their fate more tightly than any civilian. Resonance : Wardens feel deviations as personal discomfort. A city full of pattern-fraud gives them migraines. Proximity to heavy manipulation can be physically painful. Connection : The Attendance is always there, in the back of their minds. Not controlling—observing. Some Wardens describe it as a patient presence. Others as a weight they can never put down. Life-Debt : Attunement shortens life. The connection draws on vital energy. Most Wardens don't reach old age. They burn out, consumed by the link that gives them power. The Attendance: What Wardens Serve The Open Secret Wardens know that something answers when they use their abilities. They don't call it The Weaver—that's for civilians. Among themselves, they use the same term as senior Loom-Keepers: The Attendance . Most Wardens believe The Attendance is: - An aspect of the divine Weaver - A messenger or servant of Fate - The voice of the pattern itself, given presence Some Wardens suspect: - The Attendance is an Elsewhere entity - Their attunement is a pact they didn't fully understand - They're serving something with its own agenda This suspicion is not heresy—it's occupational hazard. Wardens spend their lives detecting manipulation. Some start to wonder if they're being manipulated themselves. The Relationship The Attendance: - Provides information when Wardens query - Guides attention toward significant deviations - Offers... suggestions. Urges. Directions that feel like their own ideas. - Never forces action. Always presents as assistance. - Rewards success with a sense of rightness, harmony, completion. - Responds to failure with... nothing. Silence. Which somehow feels worse. The most dangerous Wardens are the ones who've stopped questioning whether their judgment is their own. Methods and Practices Investigation Detection : - Loom-data analysis (Calculators identify statistical anomalies) - Pattern-Sight (Wardens scanning crowds for deviation-impressions) - Informants (the Order has networks in every district) - Tip-lines (civilians reporting suspicious pattern-behavior) - The Attendance (sometimes it simply... directs attention) Verification : - Registry check (confirming recorded Sórscad) - Prediction-review (what should this person be doing?) - Outcome analysis (what are they actually doing?) - Pattern-reading (direct examination by attuned Warden) - Interrogation (what do they know, and how do they know it) Arrest and Detention Wardens have broad authority: - Can detain anyone for pattern-verification - Can enter premises where deviation is suspected - Can compel testimony from civilians - Can hold suspects indefinitely pending investigation Limitations : - Cannot execute without judgment (except immediate threat) - Cannot detain the pattern-privileged without Prior authorization - Cannot operate outside their territorial jurisdiction - Cannot interfere with other Loom-Keeper operations In practice, limitations are flexible. Wardens have significant discretion. Abuse is common, especially against the pattern-constrained who have no advocates. Judgment Minor Deviations : - Judged by the arresting Warden - Sentences: fines, pattern-counseling, restricted movement, labor assignment - No appeal to higher authority - Recorded in subject's Registry file Major Deviations : - Judged by Prior tribunal - Sentences: imprisonment, pattern-modification attempt, indentured service, execution - Limited appeal to High Warden - Permanent Registry marking Extraordinary Deviations : - Judged by High Warden or Synod directly - Reserved for: practitioners, nobility, institutional actors, mass manipulation - Sentences: public execution, family-pattern marking, institutional dissolution - No appeal Execution Methods The Order believes execution should serve Fate, not just end a life. Pattern-Severance : The condemned's Sórscad is ritually dissolved before death. They die without a pattern, without a core to bind, without anything to sell to Elsewhere. Complete annihilation. Fate-Feeding : The condemned is killed in a way that maximizes Pattern Residue harvest. Their death serves The Loom directly. Their pattern-energy fuels the system that caught them. Public Correction : Traditional execution with public announcement of deviation type. Educational function—showing civilians what happens to pattern-evaders. Specializations The Orthodoxy Wardens Standard enforcement. Investigate deviation, arrest offenders, pass judgment. The most common type, the ones civilians know. The Calculator Corps Analysts who never leave the archives. They read data patterns, identify manipulation signatures, predict where deviation will occur. They direct field Wardens to targets. The Echo-Hunters Specialize in Core Binding violations. Track illegal echo-harvesting, pattern-balancing operations, Registry manipulation through echo-contamination. They carry their own echoes—captured from previous targets. The Flesh-Finders Specialize in Flesh Shaping violations. Hunt unlicensed Shapers, mimic-makers, blood-sourcing operations. They understand homunculi well enough to identify them on sight. The Pact-Breakers Specialize in Elsewhere-related violations. Extremely dangerous work. Track illegal pact-brokers, investigate substitution schemes, handle cases where Elsewhere interference is suspected. Some have made their own pacts, using the enemy's tools against them. The Thread-Cutters Specialize in Fate Threading violations. Hunt threaders who've pulled without license, extracted selves operating independently, fate-speculators manipulating pattern-markets. They're attuned to spot narrowed fate-webs. The Spore-Burners Specialize in Colony Hosting violations. Track feral colonies, illegal infection operations, hosts operating outside registration. They carry antifungal compounds and know how to identify contaminated pattern-readings. The Warden's Dilemma The Theology of Enforcement If Fate determines everything, how can anyone deviate? If deviation is impossible, why do Wardens exist? The Orthodox Answer : - Deviation is part of Fate too - The Weaver allows deviation so that correction can occur - Wardens are fated to catch deviants - The system is self-consistent if you don't think too hard The Uncomfortable Truth : - If Wardens are fated to catch deviants, are deviants fated to deviate? - If so, is punishment just? They couldn't help it. - If not, then Fate doesn't determine everything. And the whole system is in question. Most Wardens don't think about this. The ones who do either leave the Order or become its most zealous members—doubling down to escape the doubt. The Selection Problem The Order recruits based on pattern. Wardens tend to have patterns that include: - Duty-Drive (obligation) - Hunt-Path (pursuit) - Chain-Bond (service) - Threshold-Death (violence-adjacent mortality) These patterns create good enforcers. They also create people predisposed to: - Following orders without question - Pursuing targets with obsessive focus - Accepting hierarchical authority - Being comfortable with violence The Order selects for zealotry. This is intentional. An Order full of questioners wouldn't function. The Attunement Trap Once attuned, Wardens can't really leave. Pattern-Lock means they'll feel wrong doing anything else Resonance means they'll feel deviations everywhere they go Connection means The Attendance is always watching Life-Debt means they're already dying; might as well serve The Order doesn't need to threaten defectors. The attunement is the chain. Walk away, and you spend your shortened life feeling wrong about everything, with something patient watching your failure. Some walk away anyway. They don't last long. Public Perception Among the Faithful Wardens are holy warriors. Protectors of cosmic order. Stern but necessary. You thank them for their service even as you hope never to meet one. Among the Pattern-Privileged Wardens are useful tools. They keep the system running, enforce the rules that benefit the privileged. Occasionally inconvenient when they enforce rules without regard for status—but usually manageable. Among the Pattern-Constrained Wardens are terror. They arrive, they accuse, they judge. Your word against theirs. Your pattern against The Loom's prediction. You're guilty before investigation begins because your pattern says you should be guilty. Among Practitioners Wardens are occupational hazard. Every practitioner of the Five Arts operates in gray zones. The Order is always watching. The question isn't whether you're violating something—it's whether you're violating something they care about this month. The Order and the Elsewhere The Uncomfortable Parallels The Warden attunement looks, to outside observers, remarkably like a pact. Exchange of something (pattern-lock) for power Ongoing connection to an external entity Shortened lifespan Guidance that feels like your own thoughts Difficulty leaving the relationship The Order insists this is different: - The Attendance is divine, not demonic - Attunement serves Fate, not a faction's agenda - Wardens maintain free will (they just choose correctly) - The cost is sacrifice, not transaction Critics note: - "Divine" and "Elsewhere" aren't mutually exclusive - Agenda opacity doesn't mean agenda absence - "Choosing correctly" and "compulsion" look the same from outside - Sacrifice and transaction are both exchanges The Accountants Theory Some scholars note that The Attendance behaves remarkably like The Accountants—the Elsewhere faction obsessed with debts, ledgers, and balance. Pattern-enforcement ensures debts are paid Deviation-correction maintains balanced ledgers The Loom's predictions are contracts reality must honor Wardens are collection agents If true, this means: - The entire Orthodox system serves an Elsewhere agenda - Wardens are pact-bound and don't know it - The Order is the largest Elsewhere cult in existence - "Fate" is a brand name for a specific faction's influence This theory is heresy. It's also unfalsifiable. And it keeps certain people awake at night.
